Living in Southern California this was just OK. Not one of my favorites. Found it a bit bland. Even tried a tequila Anejo float and it was a bit better, but not one of my favourites.

Fever-tree Mexican lime soda works well.
Agree about the triple sec. Can leave out and still excellent.
A Texan says this is a winner on a hot day. You can cut back or even leave out the triple sec.
Well balanced and festive. Will add this one to my repertoire.

Wow. What a wonderful after-dinner drink. Like all of Simon's cocktails, they are perfectly balanced and exactly to our tastes. Was great with a large slice of Christmas Cake made with plenty of rum. Perfect evening.

Made with Tippelman's falernum syrup, Appleton 8, and Smith & Cross, along with some demerara simple. Quite a tasty drink, the falernum neatly underscores the funky rum elements. I agree that the simple syrup is necessary to really bring out all of the drink's components, otherwise it is just too tart and one-note for my palate.

Tasty! Like most drinks with falernum in it, a quality one will make or break the drink, I find. On top of being prepared to adjust sweetness levels based on that falernum, I've also seen recipes modify the ratios of rum used as well, but 1/3oz Wray & Nephew seems right to me here.
To me it was pretty foul without 10-15ml of syrup, by which time it was delicious!
I've just tweaked the recipe and added a touch of sugar. Hopefully now better balanced.
Great rum cocktail. A bit sour, but great for sipping.
Not nearly sweet enough using my homemade falernum #9.

I love this. Made it with Laphroaig because that felt closest to Talisker in my cabinet. Worth a try even if you don’t love the individual components but enjoy a complex and balanced drink. Obviously it’s got more savoury notes than many cocktails but if you like sherry and/or dirty martinis, give it a shot!
Delicious and so many dimensions of flavours compared to other cocktails. Smoky malt is a must though
Was not sure about the combination of ingredients, but it works. It is a bit smoky and spicy at the same time. Wonderful evening cocktail.
That... is unique! The smoke, brine, raisin, and delicate touch of anise. Not to mention the lemon accent. What a combo! That's definitely going into my stock rotation.
It tastes and looks like a Diabolo grenadine served in a Parisian cafe... for adults ! Excellent for hot afternoons with friends to reminisce about childhood memories !
I used Chambord instead of the Giffard Creme de Framboise and omitted the soda water and had a very nice balanced drink, not overly sweet.
Agree 100% with John Hinojos…
Great variation of the Manhattan. Smooth with just a hint of orange. Nice mild hints from the two vermouths. Perfect for before dinner.
it's a rye whiskey sour with a teeny bite of absinthe, what's not to love? Hall of Fame 56/291
I need to work on the snake at the end. I took John's lead and added a couple of sprays of absinthe; it gave it a nose that the listed recipe lacked.

Outstanding. Perfect warm day cocktail before dinner. Taste of pepper, herbs, and citrus all blend well to create a uniform burst of flavour. Being big absinthe drinkers, we added a few sprays of additional absinthe on the top. On my favourites. Love these classic cocktails.

Pretty well balanced, though I think I was a little heavy have with the bitters. Improved as it went down the glass, so to speak. Elijah Craig and all else per spec. Tasty tho not in love at this point.
Heavy handed
Ramazzotti cannot be bought for love or money where we are. So we went with Amaro Nardini. It was lovely but perhaps there are better substitutes?
I’d prob go Averna, or maybe Lucano. Or a blend of the two.
An agreeable combination of flavors with a fresh orangy lead. Hints of mint from the Strega and a lot of subtle complexity complement well my otherwise budgety bourbon.

Made it with Rough Rider bourbon, and to prevent the Ramazzotti from getting lost as Frederic D. observed I increased it to 1 oz. Strega is pretty potent stuff and I can’t say it was “lost” amongst the other ingredients. I would claim better balance instead. Very tasty variation on the Rebennack #1.

Made this with Elijah Craig. I might need to either switch to a less assertive bourbon, or dial it back to 1.5 Oz. as in the #1, because the Strega and Ramazzotti were getting lost. Still a tasty drink, but in need of some tinkering to match my palate.
wow thats a really intense raspberry taste, very nice. i used narancello cuz i dont have lemon but i can definitely see how an acidic addition would make it better
This looks nice. Should you muddle the raspberries?

Simply perfect.
This cocktail is perfect for every body and to use ginger without problem.

I tried 2 versions - one with Cynar as per the recipe, and one with Sfumato (a rabarbaro amaro). Both had the same result - the amaro leads the nose and initial taste, then yield to the port and scotch briefly, before the bitterness of the amaro rushes back and dominates the finish. Good, but not great.

made it with nardini submix (averna2 : cynar2: fernet1) instead of only cynar cause the comments weren't very positive about it. And i really like it, though the scotch does really die and only leaves a slight malty feel, ruby port and the nardini submix plays very well together.
All I get is Cynar, no Scotch or Port.
Very subtle and complex. The blend and balance are exceptional. Certainly greater than the sum of its parts.
What a wonderful aperitif. None of the ingredients outshine the other. Lavender adds just a hint of floral. Not overly sweet which was nice.

Sipping this right now, I was looking for a cocktail to use my Averna Amaro (this was chosen before I noticed the Black Sabbath one). Well I am a bit surprised this only made a 3.5 stars. This is soooo our type of cocktail and the balance with the two sweet ingredients is perfect, and the mild bitterness is just right for me.
I'm always tweaking to improve recipes. I originally uploaded this recipe back in April 2016 so now 7 years on.
Funny that Icould swear the lavender bitters were added here in the last 2 weeks ?

This sounds interesting. I’d love to know what the original recipe was to see what your adaptations are. In fact, it would be great if, when you adapt a recipe, you could also always give the original, as you already do in some cases. Thank you.
Unless I stipulate a change in proportions, it’s usually just the brands used that “adapted” refers to. I also always convert 1:1 “simple” syrups into 2:1 “rich” syrups.

Went back to the original version. I can see the reason for tweaking back the rye and Luxardo, but I really enjoyed the directness of the rye and sweet fruity maraschino. Very warming and flavoursome. Room for both versions I guess.
Further experimentation with this one. It really is a cracker of a cocktail and allows for play 😉. Sazerac rye and carpano this evening. 10ml Luxardo is spot on. Definitely a favourite Manhattan.
On the rocks was also excellent!
Made from Book recipe which slightly differs from this site….such a wonderful drink …only some of my top ten favorite ingredients…sip and enjoy….!
Thanks, Dave. For reference for others, I have added our previous recipe above.
Not exactly textbook, but I do find adding a dash of angostura and/orange bitters, especially when served old fashioned style, adds an aroma and taste component that aids deliciousness.

Punt e mes is great, but if you're like me and don't like to keep multiple open bottles of vermouth in the fridge, you can get something very close by adding quina liquor or frankly any bitter amaro to your regular sweet vermouth of choice.
Made this a few times over the years and wasn't sufficiently pleased... tonight I tried 4:2:1 with Elijah Craig straight rye; turned out the best expression. (11 Nov 2023, 4:30a)
have prev had served to me with half/half punt e mes and Carpano Antica, and 4 drops angostura and 2 drops orange bitters, all of which worked well. Gospel rye and 10ml Luxardo.
Rich and fulsome, with a surprising complexity. And then I read Pascal's comment below and added a Laphroaig 10 topper. Absolutely divine.
Nice, sturdy cocktail. Very warm, with gentle fruitiness from the Luxardo. I added a couple of dashes of cherry bitters. Delightful.
Nice and fruity, really quite refreshing. I wouldn't say it was a 7 on the boozy scale, more a 6?
Thanks, Louise. Agreed, I've dropped to a 6 on the boozy scale.

Really nice drink, and the sugar rim is interesting, in that it oscillates the drink's balance. No sugar rim results in a balanced drink on the sour side, but the rim makes it balanced on the sweet side. Everything combines well, and I personally find that all components come through just a bit more with the sugar rim.
Just perfect for this hot Sunday afternoon. Flavour explosion in a coupe glass! The lemon juice makes this cocktail sparkle.
Glorious! I used a Cutie mandarin/clementine for the orange juice so left out the simple syrup since they are so sweet. It was perfect.

This is outstanding. You get the wonderful tastes of the juices, the herbal of the gin, and the hint of cognac from the Grand Marnier. Left out the sugar syrup as our oranges were very sweet, but test your orange juice sweetness before you would do this.

I made this with Wild Turkey 101 that I finished in a 1 liter oak cask conditioned with Cabernet Sauvignon. No fresh wine. That said, this was a delicious cocktail that was different enough from a Brooklyn to make it a little interesting. Not sure its worth aging bourbon just for this cocktail, but I'd definitely experiment if I had a nice bottle of red I'm either finishing (or starting).
Not noticeably different from a Brooklyn. Maybe up the wine next time.
Loved the blending of the flavours and the hints of the tannin from the wine. Was not a sweet as some other similar drinks. Great colour. Would definitely have again. Perfect for before dinner.
Was a bit unsure about this one at first, but as the cocktail breathed it took on a softer more balanced flavour. Would be perfect after a nice dinner or as an evening sipper.
A fairly dry, citrus sour cocktail. Raspberry and Cognac forward with a citrus finish

Made this with Courvoisier Cognac and another brand of Cranberry Juice - The juice and cognac hits the tastes buds first and notes of berries from both the Chambord and garnish comes shortly after. Unfortunately I put too much lime juice which made the drinks overall taste more sour than anything
Lovely balance of flavours between sweet and tangy. Packed with orange flavours and a real treat.
Many thanks for pointing this out. I've corrected to blood orange juice.
I made a version using a house made red currant and vanilla jelly, the result was easy drinking and pleasant.
Was looking for a cocktail with redcurrants, and this one didn't disappoint. Delicious!

As a Canadian, I've had my fair share of Caesars (Bloody Mary's, with Clamato), but this must be my first with gin. I am pleasantly impressed. I think the sugar is necessary, though I would add more lemon.
Usually, I toss the squeezed wedge into the drink.
A lime wedge would indeed add to flavour and appearance. Thanks, Michael.

This was fantastic. And I would agree with other expressing the sentiment that sugar (syrup) is not necessary for this (at least at this measure). I was in the same boat as Jesse M in that I had all of these ingredients at hand. Trying to clear out my supplies. Not a major deviation on my own recipe for a Bloody Mary, but this was still a winner. (9 Oct 2022, 3:07a)

Yeah, hmm... Made it again right after the first attempt... While the sans-sugar is better, it might need a boost from spice and/or citrus... This is one of them ongoing artistic pursuits haha. Never be perfection.

Just made this given Difford's rating and the fact I happened to have every ingredient luring around...and was pleasantly surprised. Tried with freshly juiced tomatoes (as opposed to tomato juice) and it’s fabulously light and refreshing. Recommended.
Omitted the sugar, slightly upped the juice - tasty!
Agreed - there’s no need for sugar. Perfect flight on a plane, when your taste buds are dulled
Tastes even better than a Bloody Mary! Perfect for brunch.

are the volumes correct? Looks (and may taste) like it's the other way around?

Just tried and I found 50/50 gave a good result. I've also amended the method as seemed to work best pouring both at the same time. I struggled to make the result look as good as I did for the photo taken 20 years ago.

so how do we make this better ? leave out the tasteless vodka, 55ml RUM (preferbly 6 yo + ), no grenadine, replace that with 15ml Falernum, and 20ml orgeat syrup then up the lime to a full lime at 22.5ml ... delicious.
Dial back the pineapple juice and grenadine to make it dryer and more interesting

A true and wonderful tiki drink. The flavours all work wonderfully together. We did back off the grenadine by 1/2 as it is sweet. If you like sweet tiki drinks, use the full amount. It is a great colour for serving at a summer event.

I didn't have strawberry syrup, so to try to keep some of the flavor profile, I muddled 1/2 of a strawberry and used simple syrup.
What a great summer time cocktail. Very tropical/Caribbean flavors present, and somewhat reminiscent of a rum-runner. Will definitely add to summer rotation.
I halved the orange juice and replaced Demerara syrup in lieu of Strawberry, spot on
Being big rum drinkers, felt this was missing some of the Jamaican funk. Added 1/4 oz dark Jamaican rum to add some depth of molasses flavour and more funk. Loved it.
replaced the strawberry syrup with 15 ml of grenadine syrup. Wow that was good !
Some people uses the strawberry syrup homemade, I've used Monin brand
Homemade strawberry syrup is delicious but needs good ripe strawberries and is a faff to make.

My take on this for tonight:
0.5 oz. Lime Juice (sour) 1
1 oz. Grenadine (sweet) 2
1.5 oz. W&N (strong) 3
2 oz. Pineapple juice (weak and part sweet) 4 combined with OJ
2 oz. orange juice
I also added about 1 tablespoon and a half of strawberry jam I had in the fridge.
This ended up probably a bit sweet, so I'd ditch the Grenadine and go full strawberry. Syrup or preserves, probably syrup, maybe 1 oz. or to taste for sweet/strawberry flavor.

Ooh, that didn't format well. The number after the close bracket is the ratio in the basic recipe.
I might also go with 2 oz. of W&N but it's probably good as-is unless you want it stronger. You can taste it just a bit which is probably good.

I watched a YouTube video of an old Jamaican guy making rum punch in a large batch check said the basic recipe was 1 part sour (lime juice), 2 parts sweet (strawberry syrup from Jamaica), 3 parts strong (the wray & nephew), and 4 parts weak (which was water in the basic version).

But! His upgraded version was similar to this drink with orange and pineapple juice, which are part weak and part sweet, so left the strawberry till last and added to taste basically, but his "secret ingredient" was ginger paste concentrate, again from Jamaica, but I'd think you could use some ginger beer and not have to water it down with more juice like he did. So I'm going to try and balance this like he did that bowl full.
Adding grapefruit bitters is inspired.
Life was a bit too dull so on the 7th day, after a short nap, God sent us Simon Difford! What a lovely drink again. Each ingredient falls into place rather nicely, lovely balance.

Interesting cocktail. The wine was actually palate forward, with the Gentian following close and the Calvados closing the deal. Pisco just provided the alcohol punch and not much of the flavor. Nice work Mr Difford.
I was able to make this as per the recipe and, yes, it really does hit the marks of a Negroni, but with a much drier character.
I tinkered with this, using what I had in the house! Replaced Fino with Manzanilla (Bodegas Hidalgo La Gitana) and garnished with Grapefruit zest. Tasty.
A Negroni in spirit; this cocktail is better than its name.

First ½ tried a pure rye version of this cocktail and it was very good. Next time I will try the split version. Iused: 2 teaspoon absinthe, 2 ounces rye whiskey, ¾ ounce sweet vermouth, 2 teaspoons Heering cherry liqueur; Garnish: brandied cherry
Came together beautifully

Possibly one of the very few drinks, that are successfully helping me conditioning myself to tolerating/liking absinthe and anise notes in cocktails aswell as in general; more than a regular Sazerac. What I try to say is... I like!

To reduce the waste of old school absinthe rinsing techniques, I also just spray absinthe from small flacons on top of the cocktail from time to time.
Great evening cocktail. For my taste, I would back off the vermouth, next time, to 1/2 oz.

I love these ingredients, both separately and together, but I found the whiskey aspect to be a little overwhelmed by the vermouth (and that was using BiB rye exclusively, instead of bourbon). I increased the total whiskey to 2.25 oz and that seemed to balance it out more.
Tried this one on a whim and loved it. The vermouth + Heering round out the bourbon + rye in a really nice way, and the absinthe rinse adds just a tinge of an herbal note.

I made this using Amaro Montenegro because I had no Averno on hand. Not good, a bit sharp really. But I suspect the real problem was the grappa. Is there a question mark over Grappa di Moscato acquired from the bargains section of a Napoli supermarket?????
Had this for an after-dinner/evening sipper, and it was perfect. The hint of grappa is there, but it has a herbal sweetness which is perfect for the evening.
Squeeze that lemon wedge in the glass，1ml lemon juice makes the drink more balanced.
Absolutely needs the burnt lemon - brings it to a different level.
It's genius how the burnt lemon makes this cocktail!
I had to cheat a little and substitute the bitters with Angostura cocoa and orange. Turned out surprisingly good.
Tried it for the weirdness, stayed for the deliciousness.

I had leftover sparkling wine and so set out to make this. Opened the pantry and no balsamic vinegar! Undaunted, I used Chinkiang black vinegar, which has a similar flavor profile. Gave it more of an earthy note, but still interesting.
Still a wonderful cocktail. After reading some of the comments since the last time we had it, decided to reduce the Apricot by 25%. Still get the taste of the apricot with a little more sour.
Made this with just a touch of grenadine. Very good.

This is an excellent drink, the flavours work so well together.
I used the original Harry Craddock recipe as a base, adding nearly equal parts (25 ml) lemon juice and apricot liqueur.
It might be too much for most people but i like my sours on the sour side. :)
Thanks, Dávid. I've added Harry Craddock's original recipe above.
Very good. Hint of apricot and a great aperitif.
This is lovely. Simple, serious with a gorgeous back hit of apricots...
tried it with lime juice...really tasty. anyone knows if it changes name with tha sub ????salud?from mexico
Just realised that gin, apricot liqueur and lime, with the addition of Peychauds bitters = a Pendennis Cocktail.
Did mine with 1.5 of Rittenhouse to kill off the bottle, but the vermouth (used Cocchi) still comes through. Curious how it would be with Peychaud's instead of Angostura.
Can confirm, Peychaud's makes a wonderful (and better) version.
I loved this! Not a manhattan, but a great advert for the qualities of Martini Rosso.
Definitely needs to be rye - bourbon would be too sweet - but a nice option for a lower ABV sipper.
It's something to do it you have only one oz. of whisky left.
Interesting drink. Not a 5 star, but it intrigues me. I used olives for the first time, and it beautifully complemented the herbaceousness of the dry vermouth.
Just made one of these with Schofields/Astley Bros. Dry Vermouth + Rutte Dry Gin - absolutely loved it.
Monkey 47 is an excellent gin for a G&T, but using it in this recipe is mad, and will produce a vile cocktail. Use a London Dry.
FWIW I went with my last slug of M47 for this and effing loved it, although tbf I am slightly worried I'm turning into one of those Monkey 47 cultists... been a bit of a phase.

We're soon to put live a major upgrade of our Cocktail Builder software which among other things will allow you to choose which gins in Your Ingredients you apply to each cocktail. This should eliminate this issue. I want to recommend rather than inflict my brand choices on others.

As Simon says, light, delicate, fruity and wine like. Very refreshing. Potentially a good introduction to cocktails for someone who isn’t sure or had bad experiences with strong alcohol. Especially white wine drinkers. The enriched fruitiness with cleansing after note of bitter is really very pleasant and moreish. Great summer drink, perhaps even garnished w a strawberry or similar… I’m thinking of my sister in law and the approaching Christmas (in Australia).
I used cocchi americano as no Lillet blanc to hand and other kinas are unavailable here.

After making the Vespar Martini 2 days ago, I decided to make the Reverse Vespar Martini, since it’s quite similar although I didn’t have any Kina Lillet, so I ended up making it without the Kina Lillet, which turned out to be better then a regular Vespar Martini, but still not the greatest due to my palette either liking sweet or slightly dry drinks, but after adding a few dashes of orange bitters made the drink a little better and made the drink actually palatable

I had forgotten about this one and it's has been at least a year.
Used a Roku Gin so switched the Lillet and vodka proportions to bring up the strength and used a Belvedere Vodka.
Why have I not come back to this before! The Tempus l'Areo is the key to this serve and cannot be changed as it brings such a flavour and depth.
A definite must try

I went with the Shake for an ice cold finish. Even with all the other ingredients the flavour of the Tempus Kina comes through with a lovely almost marmalade finish. This is a bold surprising sweeter than expected drink with a lovely mouth feel.
Wow. Beautiful layering of flavours. Initially sweet and fruity, quickly opening up to dry herbal qualities and wonderful quinine bitterness on the tongue. Very good indeed.

Love this drink. However sometimes I up the becherovka to 10ml, use 5ml real grenadine and 5ml sugar syrup. Then I make into a long drink by adding one large ice ball and top off with tonic using a Collins glass. My girlfriend suggested that it is now a Bonded Vesper and Tonic.
Thanks, James. A great alternative toa traditional G&T.

Can I aks what the purpose of the flamed organge zest twist is? Is it for show or does it add something to the cocktail's flavor? I'm as much about the presentation as I am about the flavor. Many thanks.
Toasting citrus zest does impact flavour while also adding theatre.
Great color for an Autumnal Equinox afternoon cocktail. Well balanced with te Kahlua. Used Buffalo Trace this first time, but will try with a variety of others. Keeper.
My favorite cocktail for May! My version: 2 Wild Turkey 101, .5 Kahlua, 2 dashes orange bitters. Easy and tasty.

Excuse the but so subtle plug, but this cocktail was my choice for the latest episode of 'Cocktail Mode', my podcast where I pair drinks with retro video games.
I used fairly budget ingredients (as that's what I had to hand) and still enjoyed it a great deal, certainly didn't need the syrup when using Kahlua.
Pretty good. I used Mr Black and subbed in maple syrup for the simple. It's a strong, rich cocktail.

Delicious, love it as a nightcap. Used Mr. Black and cinnamon syrup, the almost smoky mix of coffee and the flamed orange with the bourbon makes it feel like the wild west distilled into a drink. Absolute delight if you're in that sort of mood.
I really enjoyed this without the sugar.

Yep this works, used Bulleit Bourbon instead and it was a pleasant warm cocktail not overly coffee dominant
not sure it needed the sugar syrup though
I was under the impression that Bulleit was the standard (if nothing else given the perfect fit between "revolvers" and "bullets").

This is a very enjoyable drink. Easy to make, balanced, but leaning sour. After a hot afternoon, working outdoors, I found it to be quite refreshing. This could have put Rhett in a far better mood, possibly postponing the confrontation with Scarlett.
Had no grand marnier available so used an equal amount of triple sec and 1/3 ounce cognac. Reminded me of a sweeter cosmopolitan with subtle woody notes from the brandy. Refreshing!

Very refreshing. Good afternoon drink. Did make one change and only used 1/2 oz. of the Southern Comfort and used Bourbon for the other 1/2 oz. Made the drink a little more sour, but still with a sweet, fruity taste.
Would this work making a homemade rhubarb simple syrup ? (1:1 water:sugar) i'm pretty sure we don't have tinned rhubard sold here.
Certainly worth a try. Could be a huge improvement.

Took me a while to find the original recipe which was new to our volume 3 book published in 2003. Yes, 45ml of rhubarb syrup but "light syrup" from tinned rhubarb. I've corrected above. I now need to acquire a tin to try the cocktail.

Made with Zucca and it is a very good drink. The rabarbaro adds a different kind of bitterness that complements the Campari and shows up towards the end of the evolution, along with its signature smoked accents. Still recognizably in the Negroni family (more so than some other riffs out there), but distinct enough to have its own character. Highly recommended.
Delicious cocktail great for the fall months sip and enjoy
Didn't have rabarbaro available so used 1/3 oz averna and 1/4 !rhubarb liqueud instead. Was really tasty! Averna brought up some smoky chocolatey notes and the rhubarb provided tartness.
this sounds delicious as a drink, I'm going to try this because I have some homemade rhubarb liqueur, but also rhubarb and averna are nothing like rabarbaro tastes like :P

Just tried this with Amara Sfumato Rabarbaro and enjoyed it greatly. The smoky note on the amaro complements the bitter Campari so well and sweet vermouth mellows everything out a bit. Really complex and enjoyable drink that evokes autumn for me and that I'll be making again throughout the fall and winter season.
I just used the same amaro and it was fantastic. My most favorite Negroni ever.
A terrific riff!
A very tasty variation on that solidly satisfactory theme. Five stars!

Pretty cool drink. The vermouth definitely doesn't drown out the other ingredients. You get the grassy notes from the rhum up front, followed by sweet orange from the curacao and some spice from the Ango in the mid palate, with the vermouth finishing it all off. Definitely a try-once at least.
Pretty awful. Nothing against sweet vermouth but don't waste the other ingredients by drowning them.
Made this with clairin after I saw the article on punch, absolutely delightful drink!
Substituted peach liqueur for the apricot one specified with great results.

Luxardo Albicocca & Hayman's. Made this and the Charlie Chaplin. This tasted slightly sweeter and the gin wasn't as prominent. My wife preferred the Charlie Chaplin but I prefer this version. Either way, they are both very good drinks.
I used Mulberry gin which wasn’t particularly sweet but I left the recipe as it was and found it just the right side of sharp.
First time I've ever been referred to as a discerning anything, I think. Cheers Simon!
And substituting Cynar for the Campari would give a… Cyn Rummy!
I found it excellent as specified, using Haciendo Saruro Ron Añejo (Venezuela), Cocchi vermouth, and “Red” aperitivo by Forthave Spirits (Brooklyn NY).
Cane rock spiced and El Dorado 8yo did the trick. Awesome cocktail!

Quinine and aged rum is tricky. Had pretty good luck using 1.25 oz R.L. Seale 10-year-old (though I now think white rum would work better), 1 oz Carpano Antica formula, and 3/4 oz Martini & Rossi Riserva Speciale Bitter, which is a bit less quinine-dominated than Campari. Used a really big orange twist and dropped it in since no orange wheels. Not sure that the Xocolatl bitters are helping; this has plenty going on as it is. The real question is whether/which rum works as a base for a Negroni.
Not good. Really missing something. I added extra bitters but it still felt really flat. Wasn’t sure how to rescue it..

A bit tart but pleasantly so, quite enjoyed it. I used white grapefruit juice by the way.
Thanks, Peter. Looks like a quite different and unconnected cocktail, apart from sharing the same name.
Me and my girlfriend found it too tart. Added about 1cl simple syrup and it tasted much more balanced.
Agreed. I added a little agave syrup (to go with the mezcal) for the same reason, and now it's perfect.

I often test these drinks in smaller-volume versions. This vague 'top-up' instruction left me with a drink that tasted mostly of pastis (not a bad thing). I kept topping it with the ginger until at one point there was an interesting interplay of each ingredient. Having ruined my palate with that hit of pastis, however, made it difficult to discern which measure of ginger was best... Side note, that's not an old-fashioned glass in the photo, is it? Looks like a fancy highball or juice glass.
Looks like a lot of Pastis. I'm in Cognac for a couple of days, but when I'm back at my bar, I'll make and fix this recipe. I've also scheduled for the next photo shoot. Bear with me.

I made this with blood oranges and was really impressed!

Delightful!
I used Tanqueray No.TEN to make it and put in 5ml extra lime as i was worried about it being too sweet, spot on wonderful, my wife's favourite of the day
Enjoyed this very much. Calvados was in the forefront. A tad sweet but very nice.

Was concerned about this cocktail, but found it delightful and not sweet (my concern). The ingredients work perfectly together to create a slightly sour and flavourful cocktail. We did use Laird's Applejack 86 which has a stronger apple flavour than our Calvados and it is also 86 proof. Perfect before dinner or anytime in the afternoon.
If you have never had a Rob Roy with a Spanish style sweet vermouth then I highly recommend you try it. Monkey Shoulder blended Scotch and Lustau Vermut go so well together.
Ran a side by side by comparison of carpano and Dolin rouge as the vermouth here. The subtlety of the Dolin was hands down winner for me. Used a single malt and abbots bitters.
Made my Rob with a Brown butter washed Johnny Walker Black and Carpano Antico Formula. Thinking about a second before I’ve finished half the first.
After a few experiments made exactly as described, Johnny Walker black and Dolin rouge. Added a dash of orange bitters also. Really very good.

Made with half Dolin Rouge and half Punt e Mes, which I think cuts the sweetness a bit, and generous Peychaud's Bitters because I have no Abbotts. The last 2oz from a bottle of Johnny Walker Black. It's very nice and perfect on a cold fall evening in front of the fire.
My first Rob Roy with Glenfiddich 12. Great cocktail. Spicier than I expected.
Simply, it’s a great drink.
Perfect for an evening sipper. Did use half rosso vermouth and half dry vermouth. Slightly changed the final cocktail, but it was not quite as sweet.

Like this cocktail, but made one revision. We prefer our cocktail sour. So we omitted the lime cordial and used all lime juice. Did a dry stir, and tasted. Adjusted with a dash of sugar syrup. Then did the shake with the ice. It was perfect. Unfortunately, does drink way to easy as it tastes like a hard limeade. Would do again.

Apple and lime flavours are a winning pairing in this cocktail, a perfect balance of apple and fresh lime tartness blended with the sweetened lime cordial. I used Briottet Manzana Verdi as the Schnapps and it is a real discovery. This is one I return to and plan to introduce friends to.

Made 4 iterations, starting with the above recipe (trashy casino cocktail - I love it, but not its diabetic stranglehold), then with the below suggestions, then my experimentations... My advice (small tweak): take the Luxardo syrup and cut it with Sangue Morlacco (or Cherry Heering) 2:1 former to the latter - sedative elation... This drink was made for Old Overholt 114, which I found sucked in every other recipe in which I tried it.
Tried this and just couldn't get behind it. Used a 103 proof rye and felt the rye + fruit flavors didn't meld well.
Made as described, agree with Calvin that it's a great balance. Spirit-forward as you might expect from a rye cocktail, but the all the other elements shine through.

Made this again but used Cherry Heering in place of the in place of the Luxardo cherry juice. Substituted Luxardo cherry juice for the sugar syrup. Wanted a dryer cocktail or halved the amount of syrup. It was outstanding. Wonderful flavours and perfect as a nightcap.

J. Hinojos had a good idea with the cherry liqueur, but instead of replacing the cherry syrup I kept the Luxardo syrup and replaced the sugar syrup with 1/2 oz cherry liqueur. Also upped the lemon juice to 1/4 oz to counter the sweetness a bit. Very nice complement to the rye flavors.
Oh that was nice! Going in my favourites for such a unique cocktail. The rye really rocks. Perfect balance.

Rye Whiskey does not hide in this one. As John stated, a very spirit forward drink. It had a slight orange/Luxardo syrup finish. Having started with Bourbons and Whiskeys before I delved into cocktails, I really appreciated this one.

This was outstanding. Nice and spirit forward, and slightly sweet. Great mix of the rye, orange, and cherry flavours. Did use to California Rye which is at 110 proof, which just made it a tad better. Another hit cocktail from Simon.
Next time, we may substitute Cherry Heering for the cherry juice.
I like the left bank martini and wanted to try something longer. This is very refreshing as a summer aperitif. Would be also very nice with a Prosecco or sparkling white wine.
Delicious indeed. Especially the lime zest lead on that first sip! Great combo.
Loved this. The Elderflower enhanced the herbal tastes of the gin. The wine adds a bit of grape softness. Nicely on the dryer side and perfect in the afternoon or before dinner.
I would prefer the cocktail a bit less sweet, a.e. 3cl Elderflower/ 6cl Chablis
Adorei a combinação de sabores, mas também achei que ficou doce demais. Vou testar o próximo nestas proporções.

Nice, light easy dessert sipping. Smokiness from the scotch helps keep this from being too one note and overly sweet, though many may still find it on the cloying side.

Sweet-ish, chocolate laced, marginally smoky... Plantation 3 stars... ooh, the smoke bursts in the aftertaste... smoky, bitter cacao artefacts... maybe test a dash or two of orange bitters in there?... worth playing with. (10 Feb 2024, 10:24a)
An interesting combination of flavours that work well together.
Wondering if the opaque, creamy cocktail in the photo is a reflection of a missing ingredient?

This is fruity and sparkling one. I love it by adding 7.5 ml of fresh lime juice.
In another version, kindly try substituting Creme de Framboise with Heering Cherry Liqueur: a natural winner.
Very refreshing cocktail. No individual ingredient appears to stand out. You do have a strong hint of raspberry, but it is tamed by the cognac.

There's a theory that the cloying original spec from Famous New Orleans Drinks (1937) contains a significant missprint. Instead of a full measure of syrup or "Hembarig", local bars actually used "himbeer essig", i.e. raspberry shrub. In any case, this version works because of the tonic, and I used the St George Crème de Framboise, which isn't overly sweet.
More subtle than I expected, a very pleasant drink. I like to add Scrappy’s Fire Tincture to bring some bite to the ginger.

1.5 fl oz Averna, .75 fl oz Domaine De Canton, .5 fl oz fresh lime, 1 fl oz Schweppes Soda. Very tasty. Kind of like a spiced rum and coke w/ lime, with a subtle bitterness that lingers on the tongue.
An easy drinking and refreshing cocktail. A little sour and a little spiced. I used 1/12 oz fiber & co fiery ginger syrup instead of ginger cube.
i agree its too sour

Sip slowly, this one packs a punch! Or don't, I couldn't. Rum Fire's full potential shone here and I couldn't put it down. Nicely balanced, just enough sour and bitter complexity to back up the funky rum. Five stars for me!
Pleasant Christmas cake notes come through on this one. I find the original recipe to be far too strong and dry, so I reduced everything by 1/3 and added 0.25oz sugar syrup.
This is really nice. It's the first one I've had in a lon gtime where I actually enjoyed the vermouth so that's nice.

Best Aperitivo I had yet. Lovely drink that demonstrates that complexity and balance don't need a lot of alcohol.
I need to try the Rome Royal Riff with Champagne instead of Soda. Guess it'll be a blast.
This is a really good cocktail, everyone should try it.
Try using acidified orange juice. Leaves the cocktail much brighter and better suited as a Summer sip!
El Dorado 8, Noilly Prat, Cara Cara juice, rich demerara... Surprising. I'll revisit this.

Andded one dasj of FEE BROTHERS west Indian orange bitters .
Try that
I used bottled OJ, and not the result I expected. Will try again with fresh squeezed OJ.
Sublime indeed.
I never would have thought dry vermouth and rum could mix, but here we are. Fantastic results.
Perfect sweetness. Interesting blends of flavours, but they all work together.
Usei Underberg no lugar do Jagermeister, ficou muito bom também.
This is decent, though I would agree in upping the measure of Jager. As it is, the Jager barely makes an impact on the overall taste. Very subtle. Used Fever Tree ginger beer. (21 Feb 2022, 2:04p)
Nice longdrink. It makes Jagermeister specific taste more smooth and pretty sweet.

We felt that the aggregate volume specified in the recipe might look a tad ungenerous in our coupe glasses. So we upped the tequila to 50ml and the bitter liqueur and lemon juice each to 12.5ml. One of our rules is that the sweet must always serve the sour, not the other way around; so we dialled back the sweet to 10ml (7.5ml sugar syrup and 2.5ml natural rose essence). It's a bold Margarita and who could possibly complain about that?

A very, very, very delicate cocktail. I did use Campari, and as a result, it actually felt like a Margarita, as Campari has more fruitiness than Martini Ambrato, with a floral, yet mineral taste, finished with a bitterness at the back end. Really nice, though I'm not sure it is 5 star material (just imho).
It’s a brilliantly simple and tasty riff on a Margarita, but I can’t argue with the Discerning Drinker community that has jointly judged the Rosalia Margarita 4.5-out-of-5.

Having lived my entire life in California and most of it in Southern California, I have had more margaritas than I can count. This was nice, but not outstanding.
Found it too sweet, even reducing the amount of syrup. Did add some Difford's Margarita Bitters and it made it drinkable, but nothing I would have again.

Just tried this one but substituted the Rose syrup with Lanique rose liqueur.... It works realy well but a touch of sweet could be added if neede
Yes! A beautiful and unexpected pleasure. Garnished with a scented pink rose petal from the garden.
Quite the flavour party this drink

Sipping this right now. My cranberry juice is unsweetened but added only a dash of the syrup based on other comments and it was just right. This is a most delicious Margarita variant and giving it a 5.
I like this without the syrup and with a little more cordial. Tart with a hint sweetness.
Great Margarita and wonderful colour. Did find it a tad sweet, so I would probably eliminate the sugar syrup next time. Wonderful blend of flavours.
P.S.: I also used a dash of saline solution and drinking at the salt rim was very tasty.
I reduced the sugar syrup to half of a barspoon, that worked perfect for me. As the Grand Marnier is not very prominent, maybe a bit more of it could replace the sugar syrup.
I made it with unsweetened 100% cranberry juice. It was just the right level of sweetness and a vibrant red (rather than peach coloured).

Tried this with Bombay Sapphire and Noilly Prat, two half-size stirs testing Mariquinhas and Luxardo Sangue Morlacco. The former ends up tasting like a Gin & It, while the latter has more cherry and seems a bit unbalanced, burying the vermouth a bit. The uncalculated blend between both versions (married merge) had a bit of both. Good excuse to waste (err savor) a cherry garnish.

This is obviously personal preference, but this was definitely too booze forward for me. While I could happily accept it and sip on it, making it myself requires a touch more sweetness. It didn’t even taste much like cherry to me. I added some Reál Black Cherry Purée, tasted it then added some simple syrup. About a bar soon of each (in a doubled recipe) After the simple addition the cherry flavor really came out and the sweetness level brought it into the realm of enjoyable for me.

What an outstanding evening sipper. Wonderful herbal hints with the taste of cherries. Felt that it had an aftertaste of cocoa. Delightful.
Appreciate the recipe adjustment, but we made a triple between the two of us. Fit perfectly into a coupe glass. In my favourites.

Thanks for the reply. It's a very nice glass.
If anyone could tell me the brand of glass in the illustration I'd love to know. Thanks.
It's from my collection and I believe vintage.
This is an outstanding aperitif. Simple and the three ingredients blend together perfectly. Nicely dry, boozy, and very flavourful.

This was a revelation. Now I finally know what to do with Kirschwasser. The basic template here with Kirschwasser playing a supporting role to vermouth in a lower ABV cocktail provides endless possibilities for improvisation. I used homemade grenadine instead of groseille syrup because that is hard to come by in the USA.
What a great cocktail. Was not quite sure of the ingredients, and concerned it may be sweet. It is very smooth and well balanced. A great cocktail for before dinner.
Dangerously beyond sippable - nice sweetness and aroma. I had to sub kirsch and used 1 oz. of orange blossom vodka and 1/4 oz. of Maraschino liqueur. Mine was much more rosy than the picture.
Very different. Definitely tasting the kirschwasser. Pairs nicely with the grenadine. Dried slightly and with a hint of salinity from using Noilly Prat.
No grenadine available, substituted cherry syrup from cocktail cherries.

I like the base concept of this maybe... Use what you got, ok... Why one would use that much aperitivo AND that scant amount of maraschino?... It amounts to selling the drink?... Paper Plane is great; Division Bell I desire less sweetness... But this just skews in the opposite direction of being too bitter, biting, and brash... adjustments must be made compadres...
It's good, just it isn't quite as complex as e.g. a Paper plane.
Why is Giffard’s Rose Liqueur in the ingredients but you have Lanique in your shopping list above?

This is due to you adding Giffard Rose Liqueur to Your Ingredients. As you have chosen this product we attribute it to all cocktails you view calling for a rose liqueur. If you remove Giffard from Your Ingredients then you will see Lanique. Or, you can choose the specific band used in each cocktail via Personalise at the very top of the page.

Tried using Wees rose liqueur as an alternative to Lanique, but the result is a syrupy, over sweet cocktail. Added a squeeze of lime to counteract this, but the rose liqueur is a poor substitute for Lanique and next time I’ll stick to Lanique
Very tasty, but I think next time I’ll put a tiny bit more rose liqueur in. Mainly because I love the stuff

Hmm. I used St.Germain and Briottet Rose and I found the elderflower totally overpowered any rosé flavours, which is what I was looking for in this drink. Perhaps St Germain is sweeter than Fiorente. I did enjoy the drink, but next time I think I'll recalibrate the elderflower to rose measurements for a more floral and delicate drink
As always, used my beloved Lanique spirit of rose! It raises it to a higher level of deliciousness
Replaces 4 Pillars with 1 part raspberry blush gin, 1 part dry gin and replaced rose petal liqueur with a splash of rose water

I made this using Brecon rose petal gin and Briottet rose liqueur, omitting the elderflower. Very fresh and delicate, but I think I’d try to give it an extra dimension next time by adding a little elderflower, raspberry or strawberry liqueur - the strawberry would complement the gin nicely. I also love the Turkish Delight flavour of the Lanique, but didn’t have any in.
I just tried another variation where I used lavender syrup instead of rose petal liqueur. It was great! Even better than when I substituted in creme de violette for rose petal liqueur.
I didn’t have rose petal liqueur on hand so I substituted creme de violette (violet liqueur). It was really good! I need to find some rose petal liqueur though so I can try the original.
A.V. Wees Roosje is the best rose liqueur I've tried and I've added a link to "Rose petal liqueur" in the recipe above.

Excellent cocktail. Living in California we have our own pomegranate trees and make our own Grenadine to our specifics which has less sugar.
Important that you use the best gin you can afford. We used very herbal California gin which allowed all the ingredients to shine.

A true dessert drink Martini. The slight savoury notes of the grenadine (homemade from fresh juice of course), pairs really well with the herbaceousness of the dry vermouth, with the botanicals of the gin taking a step back. I do have to say that it is not for sore dry palates.
There's nothing wrong with this drink but perhaps it's telling that my favourite part was the cherry

I found it way too dry (this might be since I am in the US and so I am using Heaven Hill's American Dubonnet and not the real French kind, though HH's version has worked well for me in many other cocktails). To sweeten, I used 10 mL of a supermarket agave and caramel coffee sweetener, which fit well with the chocolatey notes from the US Dubonnet and the mezcal. Probably regular agave would have worked too.
A fantastic gateway drink, if you have a friend who isn't yet hooked on Mezcal.
Good twist
Very good cocktail. Did back off the Creme de Violette to 1/3 oz. Came out nicely dry and a pleasant floral flavour.

Very enjoyable negroni riff. The split vermouth makes it a bit more herbal-forward, and while the Campari is still present, it does not overpower the other ingredients. I agree with previous reviewers on the bitters - I had mine with Dashfire Orange bitters and it was a subtle but welcome enhancement.
Excellent cocktail, dry, aromatic and boozy. But if you just add a 1/4 shot of mezcal (maybe a 1/6 would do) , you won't regret it 😁
Did not disappoint. As suggested in the comments I went with Angostura orange bitters. Might try grapefruit bitters next time.

Being a lover of a negroni, this looked really interesting to to try, and jeez was it drinkable, I had 2 within the space of 30 mins.
I'm thinking it would be interesting to try grapefruit bitters, but as the other comments say, orange would be great too
Great Negroni riff for the tequila lover.
Very close to a Negroni!
Delightful! I have the 1978 Mr. Boston Guide and sure enough, there it is -- albeit with less tequila (1oz) and more Campari (1oz). We'll stick with the modern proportions - it's a new favorite!
It's a Super Negroni! Superb, and well balanced.

Made again using Barbados rum. Perfect. Not too sweet with a wonderful citrus flavour.
The choice of rum will make a difference. You need one which is not adulterated by sugar syrup.
While I love the funk of Jamaican, Martinique, and Haitian rhum, it will through this cocktail off balance. Stick with Barbados.
A very good cocktail, but not my favorite - I thought that the curacao made it a bit too orangey.
The most outstanding daiquiri I tried, though clearly your falernum is half of the magic.
Terrific! Enough rum that I could enjoy the funky nose using Havana Club Añejo Clásico. The rum, citrus and other flavors were in perfect balance. Nice upgrade in complexity from a standard daiquiri.

Great flavor profile present. The rum and the Falernum work great together. I will second the thanks of John Hinojos about this site, it has greatly expanded my joy/knowledge of making cocktails for friends.
Being a longtime favourite cocktail, I used funky Clement VO rhum agricole today and 2 drops Umami Bitters. Wow that is really another step forward!
A classic. Subtle but also flavoursome and fragrant with all the elements working well together. Made with Havana Club 3, Taylors Falernum and Giffard Cruracao.
You can't go wrong with mint and champagne! What a great Mojito twist. Love it.
My favourite cocktail, perhaps because it’s what my fiancé and I drank to celebrate our engagement in Paris in Cafe Panis overlooking Notre Dame. FYI it’s lethal on an empty stomach, be warned!
Very good high-end mojito. Champaign adds an interesting touch.
This is really lovely, though I do recommend slapping the mint before adding to the glass and muddling with the simple syrup and lime juice to bring out even more mint flavor.
Lovely. I added 1.25ml of maraschino syrup.

Toast to the Queen
Lovely cocktail
Wonderful cocktail. Toasted the Queen on her birthday.
Thanks to those commenters who suggested gin as an alternative to vodka. In which case, we substituted lime for the lemon, but at 15ml.

Is the Aperol switched to Select? I thought it was Aperol. No matter, I happen to have also Select at home.
Any thoughts on the choice of bitter sweet?
I suspect Select is displayed as you have added Select to Your Ingredients, so our database thinks that's the brand you'd prefer to use.
Brilliantly fresh and fruity. Perfectly balanced. Five stars - why not?!
great but way too much foam
You must be really good with the egg white thing lol
I made the drink per the recipe and it's very enjoyable - balanced; not too sweet nor tart. I think a splash of grapefruit bitters would go a long way.
You could sub out Vodka for Gin for a Gin Ruby, more complex

This is funny, I started pouring gin in the tins and at the same time my husband pulled up the recipe and told me it was with vodka, so poured the gin back in the bottle, went all over the place lol and used vodka. Most enjoyable cocktail, giving it a 5.
If you have super fresh grapefruit and good quality vodka etc I think there’s already plenty of complexity with ingredients as is IMO.
Excellent as a aperitif. Wonderfully sour with the various flavours of the citrus. Perfect for sipping and good conversation.
This is very refreshing. My first experience with Cappellietti. I am very pleased with it. This is a very nice sour. Will make again.

Definitely a post-meal cocktail. Might be because we used a cheaper triple sec, but it started out very sweet before having a much needed hum of sourness and bitterness from the Citrus-infused vodka and grapefruit juice. Pretty good!

Very nice. Being we like our cocktails drier, we omitted the sugar syrup and put in a splash of grenadine to add a little more pink (our pink grapefruit juice was not very pink). Nice with a hint of sweetness. Would probably put in a splash of pomegranate juice next time also.

Made with Probitas (aka Veritas). I found this to be good, but also unremarkable. It's indeed well-balanced, and quite tasty, it's just not anything special. I'd rather have a regular daiquiri, or a (Trader Vic's) Mai Tai if I want orgeat.

Very almond flavour forward. Tended to be a bit sweet, but we added 4 drops of Bob's Difford's Daiquiri Bitters and it did lessen the sweetness. The bitters also added some flavour notes which were not part of the original cocktail. Went wonderful with a beef and rice stir fry.
Perfectly balanced. Go easy with the built in dasher on the Peychaud bottle. I definitely got too much for my two dashes. On the dry side, rich, intense and fruity. Even a little smokey in character.
The orange twist is important in providing a relieving lift here.
I'm confused... it's called the "Ruby Manhattan", but then uses tawny rather than ruby port.
I assume referring to the colour. The tawny port definitely works.
Not a Manhattan fan, but this alone may make me say otherwise.
Have you tried the cherry Manhattan? Especially if your tastes extend to sweet things.
Of all the Manhattan variations I have tried. This is the best for my taste. Not overly sweet and perfectly balanced.
love variations on the Manhattan - will try this with maybe a triple sec - as i am not buying another one off liquor for the apricot
Ah, but with the apricot liqueur, you can also have the related (and delicious) Sunset Park. Or just add a dash to a nice martini.
Good looking. Apricot Jammy without being overly sweet. Decent drink deserving more reviews. I liked it.
FML. This is top drawer, much nicer and punchier than the vodka alt

As I have a bottle of Cranberry juice needed to be used it’s cranberry cocktail day today. Enjoying this one much. Not sure if this juice is sweetened, I have a feeling it’s not and could have done with 5ml of sugar syrup. Night cocktail is going to be Nelson’s Blood No 2. And tomorrow a standard Cosmo (Dale Degroff, the only one that worked for me)
Great alternative to a Cosmo. Found it a bit on the sweet side for me, but I find most Cosmos are I would add a little more lime juice for my taste, but if you are a Cosmo lover, leave it alone.
Sure wish I could print this recipe or be allowed to copy the text. Guess I'll have to dream about what it tastes like. Nice user experience!
We pull the recipe up on a tablet or phone. Works great for us.

Thought I would have a tinker with this recipe, since I had some cranberry juice. Swapped Mezcal for Tequila, curacao for triple sec and used a flamed grapefruit zest garnish. Not Rude anymore, Profane perhaps, or just Cheeky!
Liked this very much, it hints of ginger and strong lime. Quite delicious. (Who knew I would be putting ginger in my drinks!). Might experiment with ginger syrup.
Great hints of ginger, slightly sweet, and nice mixtures of flavours. Would be great anytime, but perfect in the cooler weather. A blend of a cosmo and a Margarita. Perfect.
Marvellously smooth. A perfect start or end to a night
I made this with Mezcal (over blanco tequila) last night, and it might actually be an improvement.
Marvelous both for it's simplicity and resulting complexity. And the Difford's Margarita Bitters are indespensible . Will try the London Gypsy next.

Definitely an underrated cocktail. I actually make this 50ml/25ml (ie. same ratio, just slightly bigger), otherwise the total of 60ml of liquid looks a bit sad in my Nick and Nora glasses. I'm using El Major blanco.
Agreed. Measures were a tad stingy - I've upped to 45 and 22.5.
Very, very nice cocktail. Interesting mix of the tequila and DOM gives a nice honey, tequila, and herbal taste. Went perfectly with our dinner.
I made this but accidentally used a Blanco Tequila. Really loved it!!

A good cocktail, but not a notably better than a more traditional espresso martini, or the Black Espresso (recipe on the website). If you are looking for a rum/espresso/PX recipe to try - try the Black Espresso first.

Used Havana Club 7 yo and Borghetti. The only perceived fault I can suggest is the roasty and nutty nuances of the espresso are ever so slightly muted. It's got a surprising degree of dryness to it, or maybe I diluted it a touch too much. At any rate, it's a marginally more interesting Espresso Martini, but not exactly preferable to one.
For me this is improved with a touch more PX, tried with coffee beans and raisins but rum soaked raisins and a square of RnR choc wins for me.

Like the two other comment, I found that the balance of this drink was a bit off. I tried to add a bit of amaretto like mister Hinojos had suggested. the mix was better but a bit flat, for my taste. So I tested with a bit more of Maraschino and some orange flower water, like mister Dworkin tried. I liked that version a bit more.
This is nice, but it seems to be missing the almond flavour. It seems to be overshadowed by the Maraschino and Absinthe. Could increase the Orgeat or maybe add some Amaretto.
Many thanks for the feedback. I've revisited and dramatically rebalanced this recipe as a result.
The balance isn't right. Double orgeat and add more orange flower water improves it
interesting way to dress up some milk
Great milk cocktail that's not overly sweet. Seems like you could have some fun trying it with different funky Jamaican rums.
Still wonderful. Made with 3/4 oz Barbados white rum, 3/4 oz Barbados gold rum, and 1/2 oz Demerara rum. It was outstanding. A bit more flavourful due to the various rums, but a great alternative.
We found this outstanding. Use 1/2 Barbados white and 1/2 Barbados gold rum. Like all Daisy cocktails, it was wonderfully sour with a hint of lemon and spices.
would recommend making it with a sweeter vs dry light rum
Exquisite.

The system here suggested my Hamilton 151 (eye roll) for the float, and it obliterated the egg foam. The drink wasn't bad with it, and I was pleased it wasn't all that sweet. Maybe something to revisit to test different rum combos.

Being a big rum drinker was looking forward to this, but found it just OK. Nice but was a bit underwhelmed with this cocktail. Agreed with Andre that it needed more aged rum. Seemed to work a bit better mixing in the overproof rum to add some depth of flavour to the cocktail. Did drink the full cocktail, but there are other rum cocktails much better.
Liked it better with a full shot of aged rum!
Quite sweet, like it a lot with 2 cl fresh lime juice

I used a frozen strawberry; figured it would add to the chill.
Am I actually supposed to taste the citrus slices and fruit?
No shaking, no muddling...
The fruit is more for garnish than flavour.
Flavor-wise, it's tasty and has potential. My house-made syrup probably wasn't as concentrated and sweet as it needed to be, which left the mouthfeel a little too airy for my taste.
I've used Cola syrup from Maison Meneau near Bordeaux. Well known here and as good as Giffard or Monin syrup
Made this with Bolivar 8 and Plantation OFTD Overproof. Simply delicious. 5 star +.

The overproof rum really does make this. Just did a 500ml batch freezer door version using Doorly's 12, Wry and Nephew white over proof, Bitter Truth falernum and coconut water for dilution (pour straight from the bottle over ice, so dilution is needed for a batched cocktail). Really nice. I'm going to experiment with adding Stiggin's Fancy, too.

I really like the Maple Rum Old-Fashioned here on DG, but this is an interesting option if you want a boozier rum-based old-fashioned. I used Appleton Estate 8 and Wray & Nephew, so there was a fair amount of "funk", but overall enjoyable and as expected.
R.L. Seale's 10 | Don Q | JDT Velvet ... didn't care for it with this rum.
better with cane island guatemala

I used 6cl Plantation 3 Star, 1cl Orgeat, 1.25ml Bogart's Bitters (thanks to the amazing Difford's jigger), inspired by Jerry Thomas' Japanese Cocktail. I put a lime slice in the glass before stirring instead of a zest & it was stunning. Would recommend

Still love this since I really, really like rum. Used a Barbados aged rum and a Demerara 151 overproof. Did cut back on the sugar syrup by half (I was making two cocktails so it was easy). As before this was delightful. Liked using the darker overproof as it added more flavour and complexity to the cocktail Still a 5 for me.

Really very good. Having not made a rum old fashioned before I was drawn to the idea of blending rums to achieve a complete drink. I have made this as specced, yet it works very well with a wide range of rums if you play with the ratios: I really didn't think Pussers naval with Barbancourt 8* had any right to work. The Falernum (or equivalent) really is critical to success I think, along with the right garnish.
Used 2oz Ron Izalco 130 proof (Maisano's store pick), subbed agave nectar as the sweetener. Everything else as written above; beautiful.
Probably the best and one of the simplest cocktails of all time. Absolutely divine flavour, this takes you off to an evening on the beach where ever you are.
Meant to add - you can shake the nuts off this and make it a tall drink and the rum still cuts thru
Used 2/3 White overproof Wray and Nephew and 1/3 Lemon Hart 151 Demerara. Wow. Big rum punch (no pun intended).
So, effectively, a daiquiri w/ ango on the rocks...

Fantastic - I used Wray & Nephew Navy Strength (one of my favorites) - this cocktail allows the highlights of the rum to shine while boosting the sweetness and a bit of citrus as well. Excellent cocktail - highly recommended!!
Oops - I meant Smith & Cross Navy Strength, not Wray & Nephew - sorry for any confusion this may have caused.

Made this with 45 ml Wray & Nephew, 15 ml lime juice, 30 ml 2:1 sugar syrup, 24 drops Angostura, 60 ml chilled water. Very tasty. The lime, sugar, bitters, & water help soften the edges of the rum without taking center stage. Very flavorful. Seems like a great option for introducing someone to Wray & Nephew. Also seems great for a hot summer day!

Finally gave this a shot after having it on my list for a while. I think the fact that it's diluted with so much water initially made me hesitant but I gotta say, this was fantastic. I upped the rum to 2 oz and added about 1/4 oz of allspice dram on my second pour and that was great, as well. It doesn't taste diluted it's just a refreshing long drink with a ton of flavor. My new go-to when I need to whip up something easy that still tastes great.
Really nice, I like all the punch recipe's though. For me 2 dashes angostura is was too much for the wray & Nephew I used for te drink. Next time I will put 1 dash in.
Brilliant, thanks Simon.

Replacing the screwtop on a bitters bottle with a Dartdash does expose the bitters to oxygenation and will accelerate the evaporation of alcohol. If using a bottle in a few months then not an issue. Otherwise, perhaps replace the screwcap between uses. (If you do use a Dartdash then use a knife to prise out the plastic dasher insert in the bottle.)
Would this work as well with a normal strength white rum or does this have to be overproof?
You'd have to massively up the volume of the rum but it's not just the balance of alcohol to other ingredients, it's the flavour that overproof rum provides that makes the drink.
Hits like a truck except the truck is carrying a neutron star and is covered in spikes. A delicious truck.

This is a perfect cocktail for those who want a rum forward cocktail. Made as described and found the cocktail very flavourful and refreshing. Was nice and warming on a cold winter night, but would be cooling on a hot day. Will try again with other overproof rums/rhums in my collection. Definitely on my favourites for this life-time rum drinker.

I had to create an account to add my two sense and that is... This is a very loose and bizzare addition. Ti-punch deserves its own place on the top with rhum agricole. Planteurs punch another spot on the podium with fresh juice. But to add angos to what is essentially a daiquiri, I'm a bit put off on the whole thing. Overproof rum has its valour, but to add refined sugar or any sort or ice without asking deserves a proper slap on the wrists. I would never dare serve such a drink. JMHO
When I tried this the very intense ester notes of the rum did. let me think it could benefit from some oaky backbone. But of course, as always, this remains a matter of taste.
In this photo the liquid in the glass appears quite dark for just only 2 dashes of Ango. Could it be that this was made with dark rather than with white rum?
Have to add, making this to check the colour was a reminder of how delicious this is. It needs the full 15ml of sugar and the added water.
Good spot. The image is way too dark. We may have confused with another cocktail. I'll add it to my list to re-shoot.
Superb. Dialled back the syrup to suit my taste and it totally hit the spot.

I have had a Rum Runner in many of the existing tiki bars in California. I also have many vintage tiki cocktail books and this recipe is the same (or similar) to those recipes.
As with most tiki cocktails, I find them a bit sweet. We added a Demerara 151 float. Lessened the sweetness and added a bit more of the rum kick.
Couldn’t really get on with the blackberry. Removed, and replaced with 15ml of a creamy banana liqueur I had on hand. A dusting of grated nutmeg works well.
Nix the grenadine. Reduce the pineapple to 45 ml, the banana liqueur to 22.5 ml. Add two dashes of Peychaud's bitters. There it is! Enjoy.
I honed this down to taste better and fit in a Collins glass. Crushed ice may dilute this to death. If so, then add a little sweetener to drive it.

I made this drink according to these directions, and it came out a little sweet but still very enjoyable. I think it made a difference that I used fresh pressed pineapple juice from a pineapple that I cut up immediately before I made the drink.
A bit too sweet for me. I might skip the grenadine next time, and maybe swap the blackberry liqueur for unsweetened cranberry juice.

Pretty good, but I felt like it was a bit of an in-betweener. Next time I will add more blackberry to see if that tips it in the direction that I was hoping for. Not a bad drink, just not my favorite.
I made it : 1oz Cargo Cult Banana Rum, 1oz dark rum, 1 oz pineapple juice, 1 oz creme de cassis, 1 oz orange juice, 0.5 oz grenadine and 0.5 oz 55% rum
When the sunshine arrives this is my goto and its easily customisable to whatever you have in the cabinet.
This is not very far away from a drink called a Freight Train Swizzle which adds a touch of Green Chartreuse and leaves out the lemon juice. Either way you can’t go wrong!
Bacardi 8 year worked well for this. Prominent rum flavor, but balanced out by the citrus/clove/brown sugar/bitters. Great easy-to-make rum drink.
Delicious - rum leads the flavor, and is underscored by the Demerara syrup. Falernum and bitters add depth of flavor, and the lime (softened by the lemon) give a citrus brightness.
Made this with diplomatico reserva exclusiva. Gorgeous! The garnishes really add to the whole experience. The drink is dark and sticky but smells fresh because of the mint/orange.
Added 45ML pineapple, for a easier sipping drink. Used my 12 YO rum but too much going on for it to shine, next time will use 6 year old :)
Made with El Dorado 12 YO rum, i used turbinado syrup instead of demerara. amazing Drink. Cheers
Made this with Mount Gay gold, cut the sugar syrup in half, added a float of 151 Demerara rum. It was wonderful.
Pleasant first use of Falernum and swizzling but a little on the mild side. Look forward to a Green Swizzle next time.

Quite sweet and boozy, yet it is a well balanced drink and I liked it. I shaked with crush ice to have more dilution, added a dash of saline solution, and used Martin Miller Gin and Rhum agricole overproof. Great, but I will try next time with Jamaican overproof rum.

I didn't have any grenadine to hand, so increased the syrup to 10 ml and used 30 ml pineapple juice with non-wet ice.
This created a truly dangerous cocktail that I allowed the funk to shine with depth brought by the gin, all brought together with the pineapple. The head from the pineapple made it quite an attractive serve and I will certainly be making more of this riff as well as trying the original recipe when I have grenadine again.
This is wonderful. Well balanced with sweet and sour while being able to taste the rum and gin.

This is an incredible cocktail. Arguably my favorite that uses either pomegranate juice or orgeat. The combination and balance of each here is sublime and surprising. The orgeat (Giffard) is most definitely present, near front and center, but not too sweet. I opted to add 3 drops of rose water into the shake. This drink looks and tastes fantastic, but I can certainly understand it's not for everyone. (7 Jul 2023, 3:58p)
Delicious and pleasantly sour. I couldn't really detect the orgeat beyond a general sweetness, but it probably contributed to the overall effect. Pomegranate juice is lovely stuff.
Enjoyed this cocktail, nice balance of sweet and sour.
Made with Zubrowka and some other, not St George pear liqueur. Lovely and fruity and not overwhelming.
So fresh and bright! Delightful combination of fruit flavors supported by a brilliant vodka base. It may go down a little too easy, so take care!

Incredible! I was intrigued by the unusual pairing of liqueurs but was delighted to find how tasty this was. I bulked up the vodka by 15 ml and added 15 ml of cognac for a little more body. Magnificent stuff
As you know, Simon, we think this is one delicious drink! I hope others will as well!
Very good drink. I had some less expensive Leroux Kirschwasser from long ago so wondering if a fine Kirsch might be better?
Well shaken I found this dry and brisk- went down in three! Used sangue morlacco as it’s what I had. Not sure how it might impact the final result?

This was an "interesting" cocktail. Can definitely taste the cherries upfront with the almonds slightly present. Has slight herbal tones at the end (where from, I don't know. Maybe pepperiness from the Kirsh?) and was fairly dry and not sweet.

This was perfect for the occasion. We were having a New Orleans style dinner and needed a cocktail. This was perfect. The tastes of the cocktail went with the spiciness of the food. Was concerned it may be a bit sweet, so we use 2 oz of vodka instead of 1 1/2. Was great.
Forgot to mention in my previous comment that I used Johnnie Walker Black, Drambuie, & Galliano Espresso.

This isn't necessarily a drink that'll knock your socks off, but if you want a somewhat creamy, smokey/herbal dessert/nightcap, this is a solid choice. It's not too creamy/heavy/fatty nor too smokey/herbal. Coffee is mild, too. I wanna say there's a hint of "chocolate" in there... Slightly astringent. Could maybe try a small amount of sugar syrup if you want something more on the dessert side of things, but either way, a fairly well balanced easy sipper.
definitely doesnt need to be sweeteened imo but then again i hate drambuie
A successful marriage which for my tastes could do with a bit more coffee and a little less whisky.
Superb: Spicy, nutty, salty, smokey and subtle all balanced with a freshening zesty orange aroma. Wow. (I used blood orange peel for the zest.) Will be returning to this gem. Thanks again Mr Difford.

Havana 7 as all the mentions in green color are just paid product placements and in 95% of the cases a bad choice (or at least far from ideal) for the drinks, sadly. As he states later, it's originally with Zacapa 23. I'd recommend El Dorado 12 or 15 for example.
Just made this with Loch Lomond peated grain whisky. Got cherry bubblegum. I quite enjoyed it.

Not being a big fan of Scotch which is too smoky, used single malt from Speyside and the midlands. There was just enough smoky taste to be interesting, but not overwhelm the cocktail. If you like the smoky, I would use the Islay.
Definitely improves with dilution.
Wow. This was a great margarita. Taking the advice of other posts we did a splash of water before shaking. It was perfect. A keeper.
Simple and magnificent. Great to find a cocktail that gets better with time.
Very nice. I like an alcohol forward cocktail but this one definitely needed the water from shaking and a bit more.
I recommend to try it by replacing Scotch with Rye. 2:1 Rye:Drambuie +2 dash Angostura Bitters; just perfect!
Did not try the cocktail (no Drambuie available), but what in the world is the picture? How would it be possible to get pink on a Rusty Nail? Hilarious to me!
I am sure that is just lighting. ?
We do like to amuse! Obviously, wrong image has replaced the original. Please bear with us. That said, adding bitters will colour, more the wrong glass and garnish that troubles me.

Love Rusty nails.
I have tried this drink with many different types of scotch and found the Dalmore Port Wood the best for the mix. It adds a nice exotic oaky aroma to it.
Yes at 4:1. The perfect nightcap. Used to drink these with the other bartenders after our shift.
Great cocktail. We did it 4:1 to keep the sweetness down.
I like to use Johnnie Walker Black for these.
My sweet palate prefers a 50/50 mix for this perfect winter drink.
50/50 is my preference too. It's also a great way to introduce whisky to those who struggle with drinking it neat.
4:1 or higher seems better. Or it’s too sweet and cloying
Intriguing. The Islay whisky elevates it from an honeyed apple cocktail to a drink with an edge. One to ponder as you drink.
Great cocktail. I did go with Tom W.'s suggestion and lessened the Islay. Great mixtures of flavours which all blend well.
I prefer slightly less Islay (5ml). It's still smoky, just gives a bit more space for the calvados.
Certainly benefits from adjusting according to how peaty your Islay is.

Before I even got into mixology, two of my go-to drinks to accompany popcorn and a movie were Crown Royal/ginger ale and Hennessy/ginger ale. I think I will have to add this into the rotation - made with Old Forester rye and Canada Dry and it's delicious.
Dad's Hat pretty much overpowers the Fever Tree Refreshingly Light Ginger Ale... That rye does work wonders with Fever Tree Ginger Beer though. A little more sweet and spice required.
This highball is more tasteful than It looks. Not for people with a sweet tooth though.
Just drinking one right now (with James e pepper 1776 rye barrel proof and fever tree ginger beer). Fantastic, spicy, complex and huge coctail.
Is this the right photo? "Serve in a Collins glass [..] into ice-filled glass", yet I see a coupe. :)

Happy to confirm the akvavit experiments described below. I used saxby akvavit by Moe distillery in Estonia, Cynar and Dolin rouge with a lemon twist. Excellent combo and still identifiably a negroni.
I think olives could also be a great garnish option here.

Tried this last night using equal parts of each ingredient as I didn't realise I only had 30ml of rye left in that bottle. I think that's likely an inferior ratio; the spiciness of the rye was not distinct when stirred down. Just a heads-up in case folks are tempted to try that.
