A very smooth version. I’m in the minimal absinthe camp (can’t abide licorice), so I eschewed the shot. I believe Jerry Thomas’ term for putting fine ice in a glass to chill it was to frappe (frapp-ay) it, so I rinsed and frappayed, threw and strained. Then I smiled.

Straightforward, simple and delicious. I like using the absinthe in the drink rather than rinsing. Used sazerac rye and homegrown lemon for spritz. Also knocked back the sugar a tad as I find the conventional sweet/bitter/dry balance a little overbearing.
I used a spanish dry anisette (La violetera) because I don't have absinthe for the rinse and I obtained a nice cocktail. It has an interesting aftertastse, but it's not for the faint of heart.

I've also always done the Absinthe in a misting bottle, as Mike stated, and spritz it onto a very chilled glass out of the freezer. I feel there is less waste of the Absinthe that way. Used Sazerac Rye and muddled a sugar cube ( like an Old Fashioned). Great cocktail.

A bartender at the excellent New Orleans establishment Mr. B's gave me a tip for making Sazeracs. He put absinthe in a tiny spray bottle and used spritzing to replace the standard rinsing. The bouquet is much more pronounced and announces the drink to your senses well ahead of its arrival to your lips.

Mike,
I also have my absinthe in a mister and do the same thing. I also got the tip from a bartender friend from New Orleans.
Many thanks, Mike. Great tip.
Before the re-introduction of Absinthe, New Orleanians uses Herbsaint, a locally produced absinthe liqueur, for their Sazeracs.

Replacing both the bitters and the sugar syrup with 10 ml Campari will yield a surprisingly tasty version of the Sazerac. And the same goes for the Old Fashioned.
I know, it sounds radical, but it's actually fine.
Really enjoyed it, but I liked it even better when I cut the Rich syrup by half. Very reminiscent of an Old Fashioned but with a licorice kick.
My variant: use Peychaud’s Barreled Bitters, and Orgeat instead of simple syrup. Subtle and delicious.

A real surprise- my favourite drink with Elderflower liqueur so far- it is balanced with the lime so no sickly sweetness- used El Jimador rep. and Bob's Daiquiri Bitters give this drink a little almost spearmint undercurrent. As John says- refreshing. No salt on rim but next time may use a couple of drops of saline solution.
What a wonderful margarita. Refreshing with just a little hint of something different. Elderflower goes perfectly here.

Bravo, Señor!
The elderflower is more subtle than expected and very much in balance with the other ingredients. Worked well with a silver tequila and a bit of salt on the rim.
Very nice. We knocked back the syrup a little and added your Daiquiri Bitters. And i can thoroughly recommend Bivrost aquavit. Will be making again!
Great call. Thanks, Guy. I've added Daiquiri Bitters above.
Well received at the the traditional Christmas lunch party (julefrokost) at my work here in Copenhagen - to be repeated!
Just tried this one and then it's other half, Rhett Butler. A very lime forward drink. The SoCo is actually hidden by the lime but it is actually a nice drink
Agreed, I've reduced the lime. A better cocktail when made with "Reserve" Southern Comfort.

That tart lime gives this a similar experience to a whiskey sour, though obviously a tad fruitier and less alcoholic. I like this because the sweetness is from the Southern Comfort, not from white sugar, and so it comes off as slightly more complex. Great alternative to the Sea Breeze and the Cosmopolitan.
A burst of flavour. Everything works perfectly together. Just a hint of sweet. Fernet and amaro add herbal and digestive hints. Very easy to drink.
Definitely a favoured cocktail here. Consistent with my sweet preference, I double the Maraschino. Must confess I have not yet added the lemon zest twist. Must remember to do that.
Amazing rye cocktail. I'll omit the sugar syrup the next time though.

Used Rough Rider "The Big Stick" cask strength rye (121 proof) and replaced the grenadine + sugar syrup by 1/4 oz Drillaud Pomegranate Liqueur, which I like in place of grenadine. Added 1 dash Peychaud's but no saline (hey, we weren't putting it in our EYES). A bit tart; might increase the pomegranate liqueur to 1/3 or 1/2 oz. This belongs in the "Big Easy" section of the drink book.

Used around 15 ml lemon juice and 10 ml grenadine.
Superb drink, I felt classy just by sipping on it :)

The Scofflaw has been one of my favorite drinks since I first tried one 10 years ago. This is actually a very good recipe here; I opted for 10 ml grenadine instead of a sugar split. My recipe also uses bonded rye, but I employ an 8:4:3:2 ratio. Much respect to this version though... Maybe my memory is hazy, but the bar in which I worked where I first tried this used a footed rocks glass (which I still use at home for it), but I swear it also had egg white in it. Love it like that too.
Left out the syrup, bumped the rye, used Roses Grenadine. It’s quite refreshing and more savory than I expected, perhaps because of the pinch of salt and barreled bitters.
Rye was replaced by boubon, Creol-style bitters - by Angostura. And no sugar. Well, it's very nice!
Liked this very much. Did take Jill's tip and used all grenadine instead of the sugar syrup. Since this drink is about the pomegranate flavour, we used some pomegranate seeds as the garnish.
We really enjoyed this! We did tweak it a bit. We did 2 oz. bourbon to 1 oz. dry vermouth, and 1 tsp. of grenadine w/ no simple. Everything else the same. Really nice! Will definitely make again.

What one might mistake for sweetness (and it, of course, has a degree of sweetness), to me, is the roundness in mouthfeel from the sugars. The vermouth and amaro provide more than enough bitterness to cleave that contrast. The lemon garnish is essential.

Interesting, that is true. And the bitterness comes right up to the edge. The cocktail is acceptably dry, but it's not one that I would request. So next time, I might bring the Cynar down to about half, and increase the vermouth.

My problem with this cocktail is the lack of rum flavour.
Made again with Hamilton Florida Rum Society rum - 90 proof blend of Caribbean rums and added a 151 float. Must stronger and better cocktail. Not for the faint of heart.

It was 1:30am and my juicer was going to make so much noise that I decided to cut my orange into 8 parts and use my lime squeezer. I hadn't thought that by doing so I would also squeeze out the essential oils (i think) from the orange peel, which has given it a citrusy, even spicy, flavour that I hadn't experienced until now. The ice dilution will bring down the orange flavor...

When I originally had this at Don the Beachcomber it was a bit stronger and served with a fresh gardenia flower. This time I did add a 151 float which replicates more the strength of the cocktail.
The story behind the name is that you were limited to two cocktails or you would turn into a zombie.
I didn't find this too sour at all; it's balanced just fine. It's not exciting but for what it claims to be, it's absolutely fine. Basically a non-funky Mai Tai served very long.

Welp, too sour for me. Probably a dry drinker's delight, but not mine. I increased the orgeat all the way to 30ml (keeping in mind my orgeat was 1.5:1), but it still wasn't sweet enough. What a waste of the last few ml of my Cognac!
haha, im cheapo and use brandy ;), can hardly tell TBH

Also agree that it's not super sweet, but it's beautifully balanced and easy to drink, with no one player coming out as the dominant flavor. It works just as well shaken and strained over crushed ice. Yum.
Agree with John that this is not an overwhelmingly sweet cocktail, which is not a bad thing. Nice citrus flavors upfront with the Orgeat coming through at the end.
Not too sweet as most Tiki drinks can be. I had this at one of the last Don the Beachcomber restaurants many years ago. Still as good as I remember.

Tried this with many reservations as not a fan of Sherry or Vermouth as a major flavour to a cocktail. What a perfectly balanced drink. Does benefit with a short rest for the cocktail to breathe. If you are a fan of Sherry or Vermouth this is perfect for you.
I served it in a cocktail glass (similar to Rob Roy) and it was great with Famuse Grouse.
Wasn't sure about the sherry, as I only had fino, but this worked out fine. Very easy to drink.
I was tempted to mess with the ratio of scotch to the other ingredients, but this is a very balanced drink. Not as boozy as one would think.
Do you have any notes on the history/origin of this drink? Can't seem to find any info on it outside of just the recipe
A quick search of my records shows it dates back to before 2000. I've added what I know above.

More disappointing than I expected. Did not taste much coconut, which prevented it from being redolent of Bounty. Also, my colour was more of an orange than a red, although that could be because of a post production issue.
Agreed. I've revisited in an attempt to improve but not a great cocktail. The image is from 2001 and pre-digital photography so I'll replace ASAP. Mine was peach-coloured.
Looks like this recipe has changed a bit over time. Just made it with 40 ml Johnnie Walker Black, 30 ml Dolin Rouge, 20 ml Campari. Excellent; well-balanced.
Also good with a wee bit of Liquore Strega added.

Upon further review I've decided it's actually a Scotch Boulevardier. Peat is a distraction here so I eliminated the Islay and used Glenfiddich this time (don't have much blended scotch). Definitely needs less bitter red than a bourbon Boulevardier so stuck with 4:2:1 proportions rather than 4:3:2. This time I used Carpano Antica and Martini & Rossi Riserva Speciale Bitter + dash of Angostura Orange bitters. Good balance of bitter and sweet. Garnished with dried blood orange slice. Excellent!

So, I would highly recommend my recipe for this cocktail. I’m getting the scotch, bitters and good balance without being too sweet.
- 3 oz scotch
- 1.5 oz Campari
- 3/4 oz sweet vermouth
Stir everything to chill and dilute and then pour into martini glass to have it up! It’s so good!!
Don't care what this is called or like, it is bloody good. The Scotch Whisky adds an interesting touch. Was great as an aperitif.

A mixological Rorschach test: it's a Scotch Negroni, no, it's a Scotch Boulevardier, no,...it's a Campari'd Rob Roy! The Campari is best used sparingly. I wanted some peat (but not too much) so used 1 oz Islay (Bunnahabhain), 1 oz Speyside (Glenlivet), 1 oz Dolin rouge, and 1/2 oz Campari. Simple numbers for my simple brain. Can't imagine using more Campari (or more Islay, for that matter). Not wanting to squeeze the orange wheel, added a dash of Fee Bros. Orange Bitters. Slainte mhath!

Loved this 4/3/2 ratio. It definitely brings the Boulevardier into Negroni territory. Made mine with Jonnie Walker Black, Cocchi Storico, Campari. After a few sips added a spoon of Ardbeg and a dash of Regan's Orange bitters with with good results. Maybe a half a dash of the bitters would suffice.
Jees Richard. I'm sure you're right and I do hope you get it right but just how do you handle your horses?

Yes, half a dash seems to work perfectly, and Cocchi will probably work much better than Lustau here. When I get it right, this will be one of my top favourites, but it is just bit like handling an oversensitive thoroughbred!
Nice, but even hedging my bets at the notes that scotch gets lost and using closer to Boulevardier ratios (45/22/22) it still kind of gets lost.
Noting your comment and others below, I have revisited and updated the recipe for our Scotch Negroni. Many thanks for your feedback.
Should the `How to make` section include fine-straining given the egg?
The foam from the egg will pass through the fine strainer, but the strainer will catch any curdled egg, and the chalaza and ensure the foam has a light texture.

I think this is my favourite sour. Everything is perfectly balanced with the taste of the Scotch Whisky in the spotlight.
Not sure why, but this did turn out to more foam than the other sours we have mixed.
Definitely a perfect cocktail for any time and any season.

Mine produced more foam with less egg white than my normal whiskey sour. I also agree with other comments (and Simons) that with a Smokey whiskey there is no need for bitters. Finally, with aged liquors (rum, whiskey, brandy, etc) I prefer Peychaud bitters ver anga stour a.
I love this cocktail, probably my favourite and often my go to. I like to make it with Laphroaig.
Really good. Proud of myself for being able to get the foam this time as well! Used Chivas Regal 12 Year Old!
Made it with our cheaper William Lawson's. While it had a strange tang at the start, the egg white still renders it as a luxuriant drink with a nice sour balance.
No bitters at all?
Not traditionally but down to personal taste. I've added a quote from Embury recommending 3 dashes of Angostura.

The whisky sour (with bourbon) has three dashes of Angostura bitters in its recipe. However, David Embury suggests that Peychaud combines better than Angostura with scotch (in his recipe of the Bobby Burns). So, I tried adding three dashes of Peychaud in a Scotch Sour. You should try it too, in my opinion... ;-)
This cocktail is also great without any bitters.
I made the same formula with Bourbon. It was tasty
The Bénédictine gives the exact amount of sweetness without hiding the whisky (I used Duncan Taylor blended Black Bull Kyloe). Amazing cocktail.
Used JW Black Label - it teams well with Benedictine and Ango' bitters. Could sip on this every evening after dinner- but like Jim I'm try Bogarts.
I substituted The Bitter Truth’s Bogart Bitters, it’s a great cocktail.
I don't like the taste of coffee is there something I can substitute or will I even taste the coffee.

As Avery mentioned, this tastes like an alcoholic milkshake...and it's delicious, if you're in the mood for that. If you're worried about calories and/or overindulging, I reckon this could easily be split into 2 old fashioned glasses to share with someone.

I reached #69 on my Hall of Fame challenge and felt like I *had* to do this one for #69. And...yeah sure, it certainly tastes like a several hundred calorie alcoholic milkshake. It's absolutely delicious as long as you look at the ingredient list and go "yup, I would love an alcoholic milkshake and a sugar coma right now" and not expect anything else.
A fitting choice! Congratulations on your progress. I'm on the lookout for another cocktail to add to our Hall of Fame to take it (back to) to #291. Suggestions gladly received.

Needed a dessert for some friends who came over for dinner so this was perfect! I used Kahlua which is a little bit sweeter than Bebo, so I used a little bit less of it (1 oz) and added a little bit more Vodka. One might say it was an Extra Noisy Screaming Orgasm.
The thinking men's vodka orange or "mische" as we say in Germany
Why 2.5 shot of vodka and not 2 shot in this one?
Initially I was just wondering, but now I understand that the bitters buffer the heat of the vodka, while the extra half measure adds some richer body to the drink. Both versions are great.
Thanks for pointing out. 75ml was a tad punchy. I have amened to 60ml vodka and added a note accordingly.
My word the syrup and the bitters totally masks the vodka! A really nice modification to a simple vodka orange.
Lovely cocktail. Did cut the sugar by half and made for a wonderfully sour cocktail. Sort of an agricole based mojito.
We loved this...very tangy and very rhum agricole. We substituted Acqua Bianca for white creme de menthe...perhaps toning down sweetness.
I think it is okay, but definitely not a 5 star. I'm not really crazy about the scotch and cola combo, I like the bourbon/cola cocktails better. Using some Heering, bitters and saline is a nice idea.
I absolutely love this. Pimp my whisky and coke!

A little intense, but intriguing. A lemon twist balanced it a bit for my palate. Will also give it a go with the bourbon substitute. I like the touch of using a tankard glass, it adds to the tavern/navy feel. Say, wouldn't have peated whisky been a perfect navy or pirate beverage? Take a sip and it reminds you of the the 'ol solid ground! Not to mention the "seaside" notes commonly found in them.
Hi Simon. I’ve noticed a couple of new 5 Star rated cocktails recently but the overall number hasn’t gone up. Are you downgrading cocktails as you bring new in? Cheers.
Not deliberately. I'm constantly remaking and reassessing old cocktails. Also remaking many as we replace old photography.
Well we made it again and in the right glassware it looks amazing, we need to drink more Blue
We tried it and liked it but not sure if we’d make it again

We tried this, but the picture doesn't match up with the recipe - we also didn't shake up the prosecco in with the other two! It was interesting, but the complexity of the Strega got a bit dominated by the blue curaçao.
Your brand of blue curacao will dramatically affect colour. e.g. De Kuyper is a deeper blue than Bols. Thanks for spotting the error in "How to make" - now corrected.

This is one of the quintessential summer cocktail. I remember having them in the late 1970s. Designed to be sour enough to drink slowly, but the vodka flavour should not be prevalent.
You need to use good vodka as the cheap stuff with give the cocktail an off taste.
The same goes for the cranberry juice. It should be strong of flavour and not watered down. I used an unsweetened organic cranberry and add my own sugar. Some of the premixed juice can be big on sugar and short on taste.
It's cranberry juice with a slight hint of grapefruit. That's it. Calling it boring is an insult to serviceable yet unexciting drinks.
Something unexpected happens in this drink. The cranberry and grapefruit coalesce to create a new flavor that is very refreshing and strangely reminiscent of an ocean breeze.
I’d say it’s /fine/ but it was kind of boring. It could use something else but I don’t know what.
Gin.
good. added some rosemary as a garnish.

It's very easy drinking, with the grapefruit and vodka smoothing all the edges from the cranberry. It's simple to make - if you are stuck for grapefruit juice, a fresh fruit will yield ~150ml with very little effort. All positives, and it's no wonder it was so popular. May feel overly diluted to some taste buds, and it's really hard to resist skipping the shake and just building this simple concoction in the glass over ice.

A pretty interesting cocktail - upon tasting, I couldn't shake that this is a mezcal Last Word/Closing Argument without the citrus, leaning towards the profile of an Old Fashioned-style of drink. I'd fully expect that as a template, you can experiment with just about any amaro out there to substitute the Lucano to create vastly different drinks. I also do agree that 1 dash of any bitters probably helps this cocktail out a lot if a more delicate amaro is chosen.
On a second round, I attempted the recipe with Amaro Nonino to replace the same amount of Lucano, and added a single dash of chocolate bitters as Paul Green below had suggested - quite enjoyable!
Fantastic combination, I added a dash of Scrappy's Chocolate Bitters and Regan's Orange Bitters, finishes it off nicely.
No Lucano so did 2 parts Averna to 1 part Suze, quite enjoyable.

Hmmm, I used Del Maguey’s Vida Clásico, but the Lucano’s sweetness totally overwhelmed the Mezcal’s smokiness.

I’ll give a milder amaro a try, because this drink has everything I normally like.
Hi, I don't have Lucano, could I substitute with Montenegro or Averna?
Montenegro is a very different animal, and while closer, Averna is different again. To properly experience you'll need to invest in a bottle of Lucano.
I have Doc Herson’s amaro not Lucano amaro. Anyone know if this would work well in this cocktail and be a good substitute? Thanks.

Wanted to follow up by saying the drink came out fantastic. Thank you Diffords for the cocktail suggestion! I’ve been looking for a variation of the M&M and I wouldn’t have thought to add Luxardo maraschino liqueur. For anyone interested in Doc Hersons amaro, it’s wonderful: https://www.newyorkcraftspirits.com/products/doc-hersons-bitter-liqueur
Sorry, I've not come across Doc Herson's amaro.

Excellent combo, the smokiness plays so complimentary to the amaro, and the hint of cherry rides shotgun so well. I'm tempted to add a dash of cherry bitters or ¼oz cherry liqueur to see what happens but definitely excellent as is.

Nice find. Thoroughly enjoyed this combination! Glad I had the Lucano. Perhaps the maraschino enhanced/converted some cherry cola notes with the amaro. Continued to please with dilution. Good to the last drop.

Quite a potent drink isn’t it? I went for Orange Curaçao instead of Triple Sec, and Cava and this puts it more on the dry side.

A very tasty cocktail!

Discovered this by chance over the Christmas holidays and one of my favourite champagne cocktails - has an extra dimension to the classic with cognac in my opinion. Enjoyed them so much had to revert to good quality Cava so not to break the bank- but to no repercussions taste wise.
I wonder just shake pour all ingredients in shaker? or muddling mint first and shake?
Beneficial to bruise the mint first. Thanks for the suggestion; I've added it above.
It's a bit like a last word with mint substituting for the chartreuse
Really enjoyed this - I thought it would be too sweet for my tastes, but it was a very well balanced drink, all of the components contributing.

This is really nice. Everything is well-balanced; goes down real easy. The mint is really refreshing. I'm wondering if swapping the lemon for lime would give you a version of The Last Word with the mint replacing the Green Chartreuse... Will have to try that since GC is impossible to find these days.
Feels like a drink you can have anytime, really. The mint and the botanicals of the gin combine well, with the Maraschino providing a nice sweetness.
First one was by the book, second one was a, 2, 1, 1/2, 1//2 oz ratio and it worked better for me. Definitely will make again.
Nice fresh after dinner cocktail.
Substituted lime for lemon and used homemade mint infused simple syrup and Hendricks lunar gin, lovely.

We are big rum drinkers and love the earlier style cocktails. Really wanted to like this, but it fell flat a bit.
Didn't hate it, but also felt that it was missing something. The cocktail does mellow out the rum until it is not noticeable.
It is nice for an afternoon or brunch style cocktail.
If you love the flavours of rum, this is not your cocktail.
Very enjoyable, shows off the rum nicely while mellowing it. I used foaming bitters rather than egg/aquafaba.
Impeccable. The colour of the cocktail was a beautiful pink, and the rum, lime and grenadine were so wonderfully balanced. Used aquafaba, so not as foamy, unfortunately.

I used what I had: Flor de Caña 7... homemade grenadine using pomegranate molasses... The quality and character of the ingredients seems to very much matter here. And this was quality. Surprising showcase for the base spirit. (11 Jan 2023, 6:03a)
The name makes me curious is there any more backround to why its named like this?
I also found it mentioned in 1935 "Fancy Cocktails and how to mix them" with Ango and simple instead of grenadine
Try this if you are a fan of the Clover Club but looking for a change ??
Very easy going drink, perfect for someone who hates alcohol but wants to drink anyway. For me though, even with a wet palate, very boring.
I prefer it with blended whisky, I think the taste is more balanced than with bourbon.
The lemon/lime flavors paired quite well with Thanksgiving turkey dinner. Simple but quite refreshing.
I made it 2x as originally specified, 45 gin, 15 maraschino, 30 pink grapefruit, and it was just fine. Maybe a tad bitter, but I like it like that.
This one surprised me. Very well balance cocktail. With the mixture of ingredients, there is a slight sweetness to the cocktail, but in a very good way. All the flavours blend excellently together.
This drink is easily lengthened with Fever Tree sparkling pink grapefruit soda. Fills a saucer perfectly. Recipe does not mention the beautiful pink hue of the drink!
I wonder if this would be good with some type of ginger syrup
perhaps better with ginger liqueur - flavour without as much added sweetness.

Although I’m not used to seeing this cocktail made like this, the inclusion of Chambord and pineapple juice as well as making this cocktail layered, gives this cocktail a nice twist without it tasting unpleasant, which would definitely be great drink to have by the pool
Tried this and loved it! The raspberry liqueur makes it; so much better than all those cheap sports bar versions!
Thank you for a recipe where the layers are not inverted! Makes me happy when I see it like this.
This is the nicest SOTB recipe I have tasted. It isn't as teeth-coatingly sweet as the grenadine versions.
This was outstanding. Simon's cocktails always hit the mark. Wonderful evening sipper. All the ingredients blend perfectly.

Simon this cocktail is awsesome. Best use of cachaça I've tried so far and a great first use for my first bottle of Amaro Santoni. Sherry adds so much dimension here. Try these three ingredients separately and ask yourself if they belong together... Wonderfully! (Ice or no ice in the glass?)
Thanks, Calvin. Pleased you like it. Should be served over ice - I've now fixed the 'How to make'.
As I expected, Campari overpowers vermouth, pink grapefruit and apricot. Save your time and mix cachaca with Campari. :)
Great aperitivo. Herbal with just the right amount of sweetness. Wonderfully spirit forward. Balanced.
Certainly pleased me. Worked well with Apricot Liqueur. Must try this with the specified Apricot Eau de Vie. The hunt is on.
An extremely refreshing drink. Very easy to drink. A more "gingery" riff of a Tom Collins. This one will be dangerous in the summer time (in a good way).
I added two dashes of Angostura bitters, man what a great drink with and without the bitters
I used 1:1 sugar syrup to cut down a bit on the sweetness. Quite refreshing!
I tried it with Wild-Arbor plant based liqueur. For me it needed a good strong espresso but still a decent dessert cocktail.

I've been seeking out recipes including Irish cream liqueur recently (don't drink it too often; trying to rid of a bottle). Ooh, is it a tough one to weave into sips... This recipe I will have to research more, given it's history and the ingredients... Best thing I came up with now is: 45 ml cold brew coffee, 30 ml Bacardi Carta Blanca, 20 ml Irish cream, 15 ml coffee liqueur (Borghetti)... Tried my specs with Cognac; interesting, but wouldn't recommend... Interested to hear of your findings.
Victoria transplant from Calgary here: I think it is also worth pointing out that the shaft is often built layered and, in the case of the layered version, drunk from the bottom up through a straw.
Had this at a bar in Calgary, Canada recently. Delicious and a perfect pick me up drink.
Just as an aside, I'd love to see a fun feature of all the single-ingredient cocktails (eg. the Churchill 'gin' cocktail, etc. etc.)
That’s a great idea, Chris. Only I can’t think of any more. Suggestions much appreciated.
So it's just campari. Shouldn't have a cocktail name hahah
You make a good point. I've amended the above accordingly.
Oh, Thank you. Wasn’t a critique, please know. As for the garnish: makes sense. Have a lovely weekend!

Interesting concoction, and lovely presentation — as always !
But, irritated about the garnish. The original recipe specifically calls for an olive as garnish…
I've added the original recipe and amended the garnish. I like the use of mint due to the crème de menthe in the recipe.

No, no, no... not terrible, but definitely off-putting up front; first, the vermouth, then the menthe and whiskey combo... somehow, the Chartreuse is a bit lost this, obscured along the edges... Dumped it... Used: Bushmills, La Quintinye, Hiram Walker Creme de Menthe (20 Mar 2022, 1:07p)

Just made this as a belated nod to St Patrick's Day. No Irish whiskey, so I used bourbon instead. Then discovered there's a bourbon-based version listed, using sweet instead of dry vermouth. It's none the worse for all that!
Salva Vida (Honduran amber lager) and Fever Tree Ginger Beer was a great combo. Tasted like a lengthened ginger beer.
had this in a hotel restaurant in Hiroshima and it was very drinkable, I wont't be afraid to try another one...
A good way to ruin a nice pilsner (and the ginger ale, really). Might be my fault for using Canada Dry - will try again with either a better ginger ale or good ginger beer
Perfect. Have always found the Shandy to be too sweet. This is a great balance.
The proportions with this recipe are perfect. Refreshing but not overly sweet.

Delicious. Mostly rum, so make sure you use rum you like to taste. I used Pusser's and Appleton 8 yr, and was very happy. The pineapple and lime are classic - I'm not sure how much the maraschino cherry syrup brings, but I note that it is very thick, rich and flavorful, and so I think it is significiant. I used syrup from Bada Bing jarred cocktail cherries.

no pineapple around, Giffard pineapple liquor to the rescue, Hamilton black pot for jamaican rum. For the crushed ice, i poured the drink into a dry glass, put the remaining ice on my beastly blendtec and pulsed a few times and re-joined them on the same glass. the idea is shaken ice carries some of the cocktail flavors already thus minimizing overall waste of ice and cocktail ... next time no simple syrup, falernum ;)
Interesting drink. Starts easy with pineapple, Maraschino cherry juice and rum, but it gets drier as you progress, with the Jamaican rum really changing the end result.

You can't go wrong with any of the tiki cocktails from Don the Beachcomber. I was lucky to eat in two of his restaurants. The cocktail is fruity without being too sweet. The melting ice is key with this as with many of the tiki cocktails. Loved it.
A nice treat in hot weather. Tasted like an original Mai Tai with cherry instead of almond flavor, and more slushy.

After looking at the comments and original recipe, decided to use 1/2 Rhum Clement Canne Bleue (overproof white) and 1/2 overproof Jamaican Navy rum. The cocktail was not red, but had a good kick to it and wonderful flavours.

Bit disappointing. The soda water watered down the flavours too much so that all you could really taste was the slightly bitter funk of the Wray. Also, there wasn’t enough grenadine to turn it red - just vaguely pink. I reshook with 1/2 oz grenadine instead of a mix of grenadine and rich simple syrup, and reduced the Wray to 1 oz. Better, still not right though. I think it’s because the original recipe calls for a 151 dark rum, rather than Wray overproof.

Won’t make again.

Don Beach’s Shark’s Tooth certainly uses aged Jamaican rum – please see the link in “Variant” above. I’ve added Trader Vic’s original recipe which calls for the (I believe) defuncted “Ron Rico 151-proof rum.” Looking at online pics, bottles of this Purton Rican rum appear to be white, gold and dark in colour. How red your cocktail ends up will largely depend on how red your grenadine is.
Made it with Campari, pleasantly bitter and tasty.

Modified because I only had Bruto Americano on hand for a Bitter Italian Red, which has an amplified woodsy finish. Lowered that to 15 mL, added 7.5 mL of dry curacao to reinforce the orange notes without too much sweetness, and threw in a couple of drops of saline solution. Very pleased with the result, even if it's Sharon's cousin :-D
Great session cocktail. Was easy to batch for Christmas dinner
Delicious indeed!
An excellent low-ABV beverage. I had it with Cocchi Dopo Teatro. Recommended.

Not big Negroni fans, but decided to try this one as Simon created it. This was very enjoyable and perfect as an aperitivo. Just a hint of sweet, but well balanced. There is a slight bitterness, but not unpleasant. Excellent cocktail.
I didn’t have quite enough genever left so topped it up with bit of London dry gin. This has so much flavour

This is delicious! The amontillado sherry and genever give it a little bit of funkiness and complexity that a typical negroni can lack. I might try with a less bitter orange liqueur when I have one on hand, just for personal preference, but the Campari gives it the classic negroni flavor.

You are truly an artist Simon. Thanks again for a great alternative to the three equal parts negronis. The Sherry and Genever make this one unique. My Genever was Bols Original, the only one I can find in Seattle. I used Manzanilla as I had an open bottle. As soon as it's gone I'm immediately opening a bottle of Amontillado to revisit this.
Thanks for your kind words Calvin.
I live the glass pictured. Can’t find similar anywhere!! Any ideas Simon? Cheers
Sorry, I've no idea where we picked up this glass. I also don't recall seeing it in recent years. We now try and record glass used in photographs for just this reason.
Sweet and nutty. Full bodied without being heavy. Mint garnish really does bring a ton to the drink (get yer nose in there). Low ABV. Garden drink.

Very savoury and subtle. Numerous delicate waves of flavours progressively over the palate. Would be brilliant as an aperitif. We had already opened the bottle of fino, drunk straight to accompany our antipasto and cheeseboard, but this was a wonderful palate cleanser too.

One of the better stirred drinks I've had in a short while. Good excuse to use up some of my amontillado. There's a fresh, earthy, aqueous(?) note in the aftertaste, like a spring/stream or at its most extreme a swimming pool. Like being immersed physically or just sensually in water. Don't know if that makes sense. Fruity, but short of saccharine. Used Cocchi Americano and PF Dry Curacao. I've kind of been waiting for something like this. Fine work gentlemen.
For us this is too much Orgeat and not enough Armagnac. We dialled back the former by 5ml and upped the latter by the same.
A great great cocktail!
Very delicious

The sugar syrup seems superfluous here. Way too sweet for me. Maybe the sweetness will abate with some soda water to top, but the recipe as written didn't quite fit in my Collins. Otherwise the flavors are nice; has potential. Nonetheless, I'm thrilled to find a recipe with a big measure of SoCo like this. I've had my bottle for years and can't get rid of it. (19 May 2023, 7:58a)

I had totally forgotten about Southern Comfort (SoCo), a very common mixer during my college days in the Southern US. I just made this and was pleasantly surprised. Not as sweet as it looks . Pineapple and sweetness forward, lime in the middle but the SoCo comes through at the end (Vanilla, citrus, cinnamon) and that very peculiar SoCo dryness/astringency. Very enjoyable
Gently muddled the mint and used Tanqueray. Accidentally used lemon juice(because I tought it was like that). Was nice nevertheless!
Simple, wonderful and easy drinking, we loved it on a summer afternoon. Would be interesting to make it more sophisticated with some Yellow Chartreuse.
Very nice recipe. I tried it with 5 leaves so it’s not too minty and it works fine.
Very nice as per recipe, I experimented Maraschino in place for sugar syrup worked well too.

So simple to make, so easy to drink.
I threw in a few more mint leaves as I do like mint!
Perfect summertime drink! I tried it with mint infused simple syrup. It was delicious!
Likewise!
fresh summer cocktail. Top stuff
I really liked this. There are many layers to the flavour, all jostling for attention. Superb drink

Intense and rich, indeed. The blend of the numerous ingredients is quite skillful, and the overall effect is warm, spicy, and luscious. Perhaps more appropriate for a winter's evening, but also serves nicely as an afternoon apéritif.
I made this for mum, who likes an espresso martini. She rated it five stars.
Fantastic twist on a classic, not too sweet in my opinion but a bit more interesting than a regular espresso martini

Elegant and attractive pale rose-gold color. Simple formulation allows for the delicious fruit of the Byrrh and the Daiginjo sake to lead the flavor with the vodka vanishing into the background. A very nice vodka martini/saketini variant.
Unlike Agent 007, we are not big fans of the Martini but perhaps this one will encourage us to experiment with other aromatised wines, such as Lillet Blanc and Cocchi Americano.
Easy to make with few ingredients and yet it tastes so complex. The relatively low alcohol content also works well. A good reason to try and buy sake for a change!
Felt like mine needed some simple syrup. Will admit that my orange was not as fresh as I’d like and I used apricot flavored brandy. I’m gonna play with this a bit.
Enjoyed this, good balance of orange & apricot
Mediocre drink. Not at all inspiring. There's a bit of orange, strong lingering apricot and gin. I also feel that the apricot flavour is muddled in this drink, while prominent.
Very pleasant cocktail and did not have any hint of bitterness. The orange used will dramatically impact this dish, so it important to use good quality or tree-ripened oranges.
I would not call this a bitter drink. The Plymouth is very upfront and if you wait about 10 to 15 seconds, the Apricot shows up at the back of the palate and lingers.
I found it to be very bitter - didn't take the time to tinker with it.

I've just remade to check. It's not a brilliant cocktail but I didn't find bitter. Guess a lot depends on orange juice and brand of apricot liqueur. I also used a dash of bitters from a Japanese dasher bottle rather than the perhaps over-generous dash from an Angostura bottle.
Was a perfect evening sipper. A little sweet, but the lovely flavour of the Scotch whisky comes through. The angostura add a slight hint of spice.

Maybe a bit of a diversion, but I made this with Glenfarclas 12, bitters and agave syrup.
Superb. Interesting which aspects of the spirit come to the fore.

I didn't have cinnamon Schnapps so I substituted for the same amount of cinnamon simple syrup (which I had). Wow, what a nicely balanced cocktail. Great apple flavor at the start with a citrus sourness mid palate and finished with a subtle cinnamon flavor. Outstanding job Mr Difford.
A bit too sour. I will make another one with a splash of sugar syrup. Maybe it was just my limes.

My coktail was made of 30ml Xante Pear&Cognac, 30 ml Captain Morgan Spiced Rum, 20ml pear juice from pears in my garden, 15 ml lime juice . I was very gentle adding a few drops of sugar sirup. I am sorry say I will soon run out of pears.
Perfect Autumnal cocktail. Our pears were very sweet, so we eliminated the sugar syrup. Also mixed our Orchard Pear liqueur with a bit of pear eau-de-vie. It was wonderful.

I wanted to make this cocktail, but I didn't have two of the ingredients: pear & cognac liqueur (clearly I'll have to make some) or pear juice. Undaunted, I mashed up a ripe pear with a mortar & pestle and then squidged it through a sieve with a spoon to obtain a puree. I used that for the pear juice, and substituted pear eau de vie for the liqueur. The result is not this cocktail, but it is sublime. Call it a Sublime Pear, or something.
Love your resourcefulness Melissa!
taste like bubble gum
Unlikely to love but surprisingly easy to like. Will come again.
Unbelievably we had no Spiced rum in, except for a honey spiced! Worked exceptionally well with the banana flavour.
great way to jazz up that $15 gallon from kirkland!
Negroni meets banana bread. It is sweeter and I added a drop of Angostura to amp up sweet spice notes. A autumn/winter negroni and a cocktail where you can actually taste the banana.
Tried with Averna Amaro instead of Gran Classico. Seems to work.
The pulled back Negroni proportions make sense here because the spiced rum flavors can be overpowered by the rest. A sweeter Bianco might work well here. I used Comoz de Chambrey.
Gran Classico is indeed a bitter liqueur, more so than Campari in my opinion. Definitely dominates this drink. Grapefruit twist works well with Gran Classico in lieu of orange.

I used Tequila, was out of Mezcal, and used 1/4 oz of Ancho Chile Liqueur for just the right amount of heat. Excellent cocktail! Very well balanced. This is going to be one of my favorites...thank you.

It's nice.
Try it with Ancho Reyes replacing the Mezcal for an amazing drink!
Oh this is delicious- would be easy to enjoy many, not too heavy on the smoke, just enough to keep it interesting
Somehow tonight we were out of elderflower liqueur and used earl grey liqueur and wow

This was an unexpected delight. The combination of vanilla, elderflower, honey and lime all add up to something vaguely reminiscent of the scent of kaffir lime leaves and the hint of chili spice just reinforces that impression. Lovely texture, too.
If there are no comments on Spicy Fifty, then how is the reviewer rating determined? A three star rating makes me question making the drink, but I then question where that rating comes from.

People can add to user ratings without leaving comments. I personally try each recipe and decide on the Difford's Guide rating. The fact that there is only one user rating indicates this is not a popular cocktail. With popular, more visited cocktails, a large number of ratings help ensure a more dependable user rating.

Really good and even better like this:
20 ml reposado tequila + 2 dash smoky chilli sauce
(preferred instead of 20 ml mezcal + 1 dash tabasco)
20 ml triple sec liqueur/Cointreau
20 ml Ancho Reyes Original
30 ml lime juice
10 ml agave sirup
I always preferred a Mezcal margarita but this is the perfect recipe. I use slightly more than 1/4 ounce of Ancho Reyes.
"Delicately smoky and subtly spicy" is another perfect description. Classic Margarita taste with a hint of spice heat in the back of your palate and a light taste of smoke as you swallow. Very nice.
The perfect margarita

Delicious! A very tasty cocktail to drink on a sunny morning in the garden. Limoncello and black tea go very well together. I need to experiment with the steeping time of my tea though. I think I would like a bit more of that tea bitterness next time. I’m already looking forward to making (and drinking) more to find the optimal balance.
Needs more spiking. And more lemon juice. I boosted the lemon juice to 3/4 oz and added 1 oz overproof vodka.
Add crème de pêche
This was a nice cocktail. Did find a strange aftertaste which I feel comes from the wine. Almost felt that there should be another ingredient which was left out. Have to think on this one.

A nice Appletini. Since it is getting to be Fall season here, I went with a local, fresh pressed apple cider instead of a commercial apple juice (apple cider is basically raw, unfiltered, unpasteurized apple juice). The apple flavor was very prominent and less sweet (most commercial apple juices have extra sugars added). If you use apple cider, double straining may be required if you want a "cleaner" cocktail due the extra apple pulp present in apple cider. I liked it with it present.

Great martini, but definitely not dry. A hint of sweetness from the apple juice, but it is cut with the vodka and calvados. Since there are only a few ingredients, you must use the best ingredients you can afford. The Americano blanco adds the flavours you would have gotten from vermouth, but with an interesting twist.

Excellent. Liking dry cocktails, used 1/2 the amount of sugar syrup. The gin and Chartreuse adds huge burst of flavours. The lemon adds wonderful citrus highlights. Perfect before dinner or as an afternoon sipper.
I used Meyer lemon which isn’t as tart as other varieties. The Harry Craddock versions works fine, sans sucre.
This makes me feel like I have passed out on a wealthy persons front lawn and woke up in the morning chewing the soft grass clippings. It is quite enjoyable.

The initial taste hit from this was quite herby but with a tartness from the sherry and lime bitters. I wasn't sure aboy it but by the time I had got past the third sip I was already thinking about having another.
This is a really great drink - bags of flavours, cleansing on the palate and so easy to drink.
Veneziano only with Select of course
Better with "Select Aperitivo"
Too bitter for me but I can see where it would hit a spot. Maybe when the weather is warmer here and with a better prosecco.
Is there a better aperitif cocktail (for the bitter liqueur-hardened)? So bright, light, and fruity, yet intensely bitter and dry. Perfect.
Lovers of Campari will love this variation of Campari soda/Aperol Spritz. Delicious, refreshing and entirely addictive in such a great way!
Not bad... made for breakfast and substituted Prosecco for the tonic... tasty
Tasty pimped up gin and tonic. We made it with Seville orange tanquaray which was lovely anyway.

Very nice "Old Fashioned" variant. I used Avallen Calvados & Remy Martin VSOP. Those two blended well together, with a little herbal bitterness from the Jagermeister, and just a touch of sweetness to take the edge off.
Had again made according to the recipe. Delightful as before. Perfect evening sipper.
Perfect evening sipper. Nice and spirit forward. Must confess, I did use 2 parts calvados to 1 part applejack bottled-in-bond, giving a little extra kick. Would definitely have again.
Didn't have any dark sugar in the house so I used agave syrup to sweeten. A lovely rich, evening sipper.
Excellent! All fresh ingredients and home made ginger ale- yum!
Decent drink, but I have a feeling this suits a typical ginger ale (think Schweppes) rather than a spicy one/ginger syrup + Soda.

Sweeter than I would normally like, though it's an almond-y sweetness, which is a little more unusual. Other than the orgeat, it's a good way to use up basic bar supplies. I'd probably make this for friends who want to start exploring cocktails but aren't ready to get wild with bitters and liqueurs yet.
Very nice, though a bit too sweet for me.
Fantastic cocktail! I threw a few mint leaves into the shaker and fine strained.
Finishing out St. Patrick's Day in San Diego, we had this as our digestive. It was perfect. Wonderfully herbal with just the right sweetness. Highly enjoyable.

Happy Saint Patrick's day. This was the cocktail I already chose for tonight. Today we are going to a big big Saint Patrick's day party hosted by a restaurant (Irish guy running it) up in the mountains 2222m in altitude
Cheers, Nathalie. I'm now also sipping on one but in a far less lofty location. It's a cleansing cocktail!
well after our mega party up there in the mountains, just sipping this right now and very much enjoying this... Cheers all
Tried this tonight. Exceptionally balanced, the chartreuse is dominat but not unbalanced. The soda water really brings it all together.
very disappointing, id try a different rum next time, for reference i used pyrat 15 yo old age avrg rum.
Really liked this one. I like the idea of the 151 float in place of the rum in the mix.
Hmm, so mediocre. A waste of Cognac, to be honest. All the ingredients sort of turned it into... nothing? If i make this again, maybe I'll forgo the crushed ice?
Really refreshing, loved it. So did my wife - who stole mine!
Made even better by replacing 15ml of rum in the base recipe with a 15ml float of overproof and some Angostura
Wonderful cocktail. The rum and cognac blend together well and the hint of Orgeat adds a hint of almond.
Delish! One of those drinks where, rather than tasting the individual parts, everything melds into something totally different and delicious.
I like a bit of Orgeat and this was very very tasty, sharp and boozy and very drinkable

I have tried this three times. One time trying 25% of the vodka as vanilla as someone proposed - to me that did not work and the vanilla took over. One time as per recipe. Beautiful. One time without orange bitters. Very clean, the apple/pear flavours shining through. Also impressive.
I found that substituting some of the vodka for some absolut vanilla vodka added a nice flavour to it

You’ll need to juice pears freshly for this (and whilst you’re there you may as well juice apples as well) so it’s probably just as well someone bought you a juicer with the fond hope you will life of kale smoothies. Mix the lemon juice in straight away to stop the other juices browning.

Delicious autumn cocktail that I’m sure is just as good for you as a kale smoothie.

I liked this better than the (very similar) Jack Dempsey - I guess that the grenadine and the increased gin are the keys. I like how the rum and the gin work well together (even though this cocktail is more gin heavy, I thought it was light on the botanicals), and I think the grenadine adds slightly more depth of flavor. I also added a drop of saline, which I like to do with fresh citrus.
A summery drink. Interesting how the rum's sweetness is balanced by the botanicals. (Cruz Rum and Sapphire Gin)

Started mixing the cocktail as listed. Found it fairly balanced. Very citrus forward and dry. Omitted the rich syrup the second time mixing it and it was also enjoyable. It became a more sour and dry cocktail. Either way, this was very enjoyable.
I used the recipe from the 16th edition, 45ml each rum and gin, 15 ml grenadine and lemon juice. Fabulous cocktail, just the right side of sour for me. Pretty potent though!

Went with a E.S.A. Field Barbados white rum at 43% for lack of Simon’s special blend. Probably lacked some subtlety as a result but still delicious. Agree with @John Hinojos about reducing the grenadine syrup for those of us who like the sweetness toned down.

This one is deceptive. It does not taste like there is the amount of alcohol in it as it contains. Liking our cocktails a bit on the sour side, we used only 1/2 the grenadine. Very flavourful and enjoyable.

I want to make a cocktail to celebrate the birthday of Whitney Houston - so I want it to be amped up to create a 'superstar' cocktail - any suggestions for what would work? (As a default I resort to Champagne....)
If in doubt go classic - a Champagne Cocktail perhaps.
I really like this. Perfect as an aperitif. Followed the instructions to stir until bored and thirsty. It really is critical to the balance.
I had a choice of rhum agricole vs gold rum and went for the former. Really enjoyable! If I had a club I would serve that all night with loud music to cover the noise of the blenders ;)
This was a lovely cocktail. Though I tried substituting the Parfait Amour Liquor with a 1/4 oz each of Creme de Violette and Dry Curaçao. It still achieves a very similar hue as well.

Delicate, floral aperitif, lovely to sip very cold. I’d consider shorting the maraschino, but that’s just my preference for something a little less sweet. I used a dry, unoaked Chardonnay and it worked well in this recipe.
Very nice. the eau-de-vie adds a nice touch and the Maraschino adds a touch of cherry and some sweetness. Very easy to drink. Would be perfect as an afternoon or evening sipper.
Nice! I dialled the Pear William and Maraschino down to 10ml to give myself a low alcohol version of something like a Gin Blossom Martini.
This is fantastic. Especially liked what the pamplemousse liqueur brought to the mixture. Was a tiny bit short and made up the difference with maraschino liqueur.☆☆☆☆☆♡
Swapped the campari and simple for 1/2oz aperol and found this to be quite well balanced and delicious
Like the look of this. What’s the rating please? Cheers.
Sorry, Lee. I missed that box. Now added.

Talk about a mouthful of flavor! I found this nicely balanced with Cocchi Storico Vermouth di Torino and Fernet Branca. Although syrupy it didn't taste too sweet. I've got to try this with Cocchi Dopo Teatro Vermouth Amaro.
Wow, choose your vermouth wisely. I think since we’re absent a spirit the vermouth profile is much more important. Strega’s minty aftertaste compliments the eucalyptus of fernet well.
Definitely cut the Fernet in half, and it’s delicious. I added 1 oz of dry gin and now it’s my perfect herbal cocktail.
Tried this, still too sweet, tried adding orange bitters, slight improvement but now so far off the original recipe I have to conclude it just doesn't work.
Agree with the earlier comment, the Fernet slightly overwhelms the other ingredients.
Dialled down the fernet - too sweet.

I may had an heavy hand on the absent Dash but my cocktail taste like lime juice, water and rubber for some reason. I guess I will try that cocktail again with a a more accurate way to do a dash with my absent
Had with a beer batter tilapia tostada and it was perfect. This is a well balanced cocktail with just the right amount of punch and citrus.

I did not enjoy the drink very much, the combination of frangelico and campari ended up tasting like burned hazelnuts. I made a version with aperol instead of campari and bourbon instead of gin and it was very sweet, but the aromas melded more readily. There is a good drink hidden somewhere here.

Use a white Italian bitter instead of the red as it was not as sweet as the red. Ended up with a perfect after-dinner/evening sipper. Starts with the sweet, hazelnut notes and ends with the bitter. Not outstanding, but perfect for a regular evening cocktail.
The Frangelico is very subtle, but it makes all the difference for those who don't want that punch.

Actually a very nice slow sipper. Takes off the sharp bitter edge of the Negroni, that sometimes you may not want, and tempers it with the familiar, comforting, rounder Frangelico flavor and mouthfeel. Nothing surprising, but very pleasant.

I found this just OK. Felt that it was a lot sweeter than what I would expect a 7 cocktail. I would think at highest a 6. The blanco tequila gets lost; perhaps it would be better with an reposado or anejo tequila.
Can I use absinthe instead of star anise?

Infuse star anise in Campari or other Italian red bitter liqueur.
This was excellent--a great mix of flavors
ok yes. sort of reminiscent of a christmas cosmo but with more umph from the bourbon.
Glad I tried it. I would decrease the cranberry a bit next time; just my persona preference.
I feel like this should be higher than a 7 on the Boozy/Gentle scale? At least an 8, imho. (It is 2 standard drinks, after all, with all 4 ingredients containing alcohol.)

I’ve been trying to find the perfect balance for a Manhattan for ages and this has hit the nail on the head! Just the right amount of vermouth, and with the addition of a subtle amount of Amaretto, it is just perfect. Thank you :-)
This is a very delicious cocktail. I love a good Manhattan and this one takes the standard to new highs.

This was outstanding as an evening sipper with some Amaretto flavoured bread pudding. The forward taste of the whiskey and the hint of almond was perfect. Slightly sweet but perfect in the evening after a nice supper.
A delightful cocktail. I prefer it with Russells Reserve Kentucky Bourbon (90 proof) and a slice of orange - simply delicious.
Is that the 10 year?

I originally made this in 2020 using a 2:1 ratio and thought the creme de menthe was just too much. Just made the above recipe, essentially serving up and thought it was decent, and probably better over more ice. Tried it again at a 3:1 then 4:1 ratio, and the former turned out to be perfect for an up serving. 4:1 the mint is there, but the harmony is dissonant.

I think this modernized version is much better than the equal parts original - I would even increase the cognac slightly to 2.25 oz / 67.5 ml - but it's still an intensely minty cocktail that bares for me an unfortunate association with toothpaste. My favorite version dials the Creme de Menthe way down - 2 oz / 60 ml cognac with 0.25 oz / 7.5 ml creme de menthe - for more of a minty cognac Old Fashioned feel.
I like this, but preferred it served straight up.
I usually test drinks served up, but I did this one over two ice cubes in a rocks glass. Not too far off from up.
Definitely a sweet, yet potent digestif, doubling as a dessert drink, in my opinion.
Way too minty for me. But my mother-in-law loves it. Takes her back to the ‘60s.
Great classic. Perfect after dinner and with the ice. Simply a great way to end an evening.
Lovely cocktail. Just got a bottle of Lucano for the Beelzebub and found this recipe. I used Dry Curacao. Perfectly balanced sour, bitter, and fruity richness.
Good stuff here.
Enough ingredients for it to be a Tiki drink. You would never expect this combination of ingredients to make a drink that tastes so fruity. Well-named!
Also, for a drink that’s almost all booze, it’s deceptively light and fruity. “Dangerous!”, my wife says.

This was delicious. Just the right amount of sour to sweet and a good taste of rum throughout. Our grenadine is from a small batch maker and closer to homemade than most others. Overall a very nice drink.
The first sip is lovely however the finishing taste is sour. A bit to lemon for me. Many people might prefer this.

I have a problem with Giffard Grenadine Syrup and its candyish taste that tends to dominate its surroundings, so I usually cut the suggested amount to half, or in some cocktails even to one third. To balance the lemon juice in this drink I added 10 ml Monin cane sugar syrup. The end result was very good — I gave it a 4.

Like all other cocktails using fresh citrus, we adjusted the sugar syrup since all our citrus is tree ripened.
Interesting blend of ingredients and the cocktail was subtle and refreshing. Could see making this with a higher proof rye which would eliminate the touch of sweetness from the bourbon.
Glad to have tried it but not in love with this one. Gave it a 3 stars rating.

Decent drink. 4 star territory personally. But more interesting than the drink itself is this thread: https://spiritsandcocktails.community/t/stone-sours/202

It features David Wondrich and Robert Simonson, among others discussing what actually even is a Stone Sour. The first written mention is by Tom Bullock in 1917, where it's Old Tom, orange and lemon juice, no apricot liqueur. And it's morphed into so many other things since.
Many thanks for bringing this to my attention, Chris. I look forward to revising this recipe in the bar, but in the meantime, I've added notes and quotations to the history.
I've also seen this with an egg white, but no orange juice. I'll have to do a taste-test to see which one is better.

The Stone Sour (made with Tin Cup Bourbon) is a lovely cocktail as the two citrus juices conspire with the apricot brandy to soften the Bourbon in the best way possible - still the Bourbon aroma and taste minus the edge.
Respectfully, this drink is not attractive. Serve it over crushed ice in a double old fashioned to make it look like Henry Cavill.
Agree tastes like a gin screwdriver. Nothing special.
This is very, very good. Reminds me a bit of a gin based Screwdriver. You do get the herbal hints from the gin, and flavours blend wonderfully together.

I really enjoyed this, a very well balanced sour. Very citrusy and refreshing. This is going to be a summer staple for me!

Had a go at this with both bottled fresh orange juice, and freshly squeezed orange juice. There was quite a noticeable difference between the two, so I would really recommend using freshly squeezed to keep the balance.
Used a dark german beer and it was downright delicious. Will have to try with an even darker beer next time (i.e. stout of some kind).

I can tell this one will take up too much of my time in brand experimentation... I used a 9% abv Imperial Stout, Appleton SB, and Kamora (terrible, saccharine; Mr. Black is far superior than any other coffee liqueur I've tried, and I'm continually wasting money trying other brands)... I have had this with both a standard proof Jamaican rum (Appleton) and Irish Whiskey (Jameson) and they were both excellent.
Not sure about the ‘shake all ingredients’. First time with the Guiness was a bit fizzy! I now add it at the end and stir.

I've revisited the Sout Fellow and tried both stirred and shaken but I much prefer shaken. I used Guinness Original and it had the potential to be explosive in the shaker but OK if you hold firmly. I've added a note warning of this in the method. Many thanks for your feedback.

Genuinely baffled how the Raffles get round this.
Not dry cherry and gin at the fore, but lemon juice. I think I'd halve the quantity?

Tried this with blueberry gin instead of cachaca and blackcurrant syrup instead of sugar. So good! Thanks!
This is a superb drink and elevates a regular caipirinha into something else. I used cachaca 51 which is pretty rough but the basil and strawberry really stand up to it. Try it

So perhaps a “Strawberry Basil Caipirinha”. Just to check, your recipe? ½ fresh Lime, 3 fresh Strawberries, 3 fresh Basil leaves, 15ml Framboise, 1.25ml Balsamic vinegar, 60ml Cachaça

By making this nice summerly cocktail I had an interesting experience. Doing two cocktails side by side one of them was significantly better than the other. It seems that slight deviations can make a big difference

Excellent cocktail, fruity, but absolutely on the dry side and quite strong. I suggest to add some strawberry syrup unless you have really good, sweet and ripe strawberries. I upped the amounts by a third for a Nick&Nora.

Wonderful strawberry cocktail. The strawberries are center the flavour. Gin adds a bit of herbal notes, but are in the background. Did not add the Creme de violette as we felt it would overpower the cocktail and muddy the beautiful red colour of the cocktail.
Substituted 7.5ml of simple syrup for orgeat, great combination with the strawberries.
Always wanted one
Made it with bison grass vodka, my favourite for some time now. It was very tasty, would make it again.
This was OK, not outstanding. Seemed a bit flat in flavour. The delicate strawberry liqueur gets lost with the other ingredients.
Agreed, John. Citrus vodka overwhelms the strawberry liqueur so I've switched to unflavoured vodka.

Very tasty summer cocktail. I muddled the fresh strawberries through a kitchen strainer into a bowl, and sieved it again through the kitchen strainer. I find that blenders also extract some bitterness from the little stones (seeds) so not recommended. I ended up with 50 ml strawberries pulp, which I shaked with 50 ml Havanna Club 3 yr rum and 20 ml Pussers Gunpowder Proof Rum. Oherwise as in Difford's recipe. Straining ok after shaking, some intermediate cleaning of small cocktail sieve needed.
Try sieving the strawberries In advance and freezing the juice in an ice cube tray. Add to shaker/mixer when needed for your cocktail. Saves lots of stress.

As a light rum cocktail this is great and very flavourful.
As a rum cocktail it is a bit wimpy. Added a float of 151 Demerara rum. Good strong rum flavour.

When I make cocktails with lots of fruit pulp I actually prefer to: 1) Shake 2) Pass to the smaller part of the Boston shaker 3) Use a Julep strainer so that pulp don't get clogged up 4) Use the bartender spoon to help the cocktail flow through the fine strainer. This way I can even make two cocktails in one go.

Simon, thank you for the note about straining. Very helpful. Much easier to make this time. Did decide to up the punch of the cocktail by putting in 1 1/2 oz white rum and 1/2 oz of overproof white rum. Gave it a little hint of the rum funk.
I prefer doing this drink in a mixer. It extracts more of the strawberry flavor and it is easier to strain.
Agreed, Florian. Please see link to 'Frozen Strawberry Daiquiri' above

Well I've just made my first strawberry daiquiri and, like others below, I struggled to extract the drink from the strawberry mush - a right mess! I used strawberries from my garden and a coco strainer, to no avail. Having read through the Daiquiri cocktail area linked in the description above, I think my problems may reside in using ice straight from the freezer. I can't be alone among enthusiastic amateurs in using freezer ice without adding chilled water to achieve correct dilution. Stupid.

Straining strawberries is a faff but I've added some notes below. As for ice, I recommend taking out the freezer 5 to 10 mins (depending on ambient temp etc) before use (as you would ice cream) to allow the ice to temper. Even then, some cocktails still benefit for a little extra dilution.

After reading the comments, we used a few more strawberries and muddled them lightly so we got the strawberry juice and the ingredients and then strained into the shaker. Then added ice and shook. The light muddle of the strawberries still was slow to strain, but most of the strawberry seeds stuck to the pulp.

I tried with

75 ml White Rum
45 ml Strawberry Puree
30 ml Lime
30 ml Simple Syrup
Top with Whipping Cream

Whipping cream created a wow effect for my friends. Also can mix it after drinking for a while and it will become another drink.

I tried following the recipe but the blended mix was so dense that it immediately clogged the fine mesh. I tried pouring it back and forth + washing the mesh between pours bit I don't think this is how it is supposed to be.
Sounds like your strainer is too fine. Perhaps invest in a Cocktail Kingdom Coco Fine Strainer.
Can you use frozen strawberries to make this? If so, would you reduce the amount of crushed ice to compensate. Thanks
Yes. Anders Erickson has a frozen strawberry margarita recipe where he uses 1-1.5 cups of frozen strawberries and 0.25-0.5 cups of crushed ice.

Well I think I did something wrong. I doubled up all ingredients (including the ice) to make two drinks. Turned out very watery and bkand. Maybe I should have just used 6oz for both drinks instead of 12oz (doh!)

Should we fine strain the frozen cocktails, or is this just a typo? Also in some recipes of frozen cocktails you indicate "half a scoop of crushed ice". Is always 6oz of crushed ice the appropriate amount? Thank you in advance

With the right fine strainer (e.g. a Coco strainer), fine straining some blended cocktails works really well and is something I picked up in Cuba. The amount of crushed ice is more tricky and varies by cocktail but half a scoop (6oz) is my default.
Very refreshing blend of summer flavours. The ripeness of the strawberries are critical.

Rarely comment despite constant use of the site but this is phenomenal. And I say that as someone who likes boozy drinks with no citrus (other than garnish) and who actively dislikes fruity things and vodka cocktails. The balsamic was revelatory. Didn't measure 5 drops as intended. Just came out in a small stream with my finger over and then incorporated with a cocktail stick. Pepper and balsamic would seem to be underutilised in the cocktail world after this.
Works very well without foam and maybe gets a little bit lighter.

Delicious and light. I happened to have a nice white balsamic that I used for this, and I'd suggest to anyone thinking of doing the same that you could increase the amount per glass significantly to compensate for the lighter flavor.
Lite, refreshing, satisfying, Strawberry. I needed a 1 turn stir after adding the balsamic as mine settled to the bottom. The drink did not last long in the glass.
Silky smooth - I really liked this one
A wonderful blend of flavour with the Strawberry, Honey and Lemon. The drop of balsamic and sprinke of pepper added to the presentation

No strawberry liqueur. Fresh Strawberries are coming in the season. Mashed 3-4 big ripe strawberries to get about 1 oz juice, 1/6 -1/4 oz Rich Syrup to give extra sweetness. Better quality of Grappa is required. Hard Strawberry Lemonade in Grappa’s Way.
Not a fan at all with Tosolini Fragola and Marolo Moscato Grappa

For three ingredients, this is surprising complex in flavour. Very grappa forward, so use a good brand. The strawberry liqueur adds a hint of sweetness and softens any harsh edges of the grappa. Lemon adds the sour hints which keep the sweetness down. Great and refreshing.
Made this again, but substituted Giffard's Creme de Fraise des Bois for the sugar syrup. Upped the strawberry flavour.
Excellent - I made this in the Nutribullet with an extra cube of ice. And mezcal. Tippy top.

Our strawberries were the first of the season and not as sweet as later strawberries. This was a great cocktail. The tastes are subtle and delicate. Would make again the next time I have fresh strawberries.
Wonderful. Made to the recipe and it was perfect. A tad sweet for me, but I think that would also depend on the sweetness of the strawberries. Bright strawberry flavour.

I thought the other commenter's idea of a splash of lime was a good one, however after trying it I felt it detracted from the strawberries. My solution is an expressed lime zest which brings that lovely aroma while keeping the drink unequivocally strawberry forward. A dash of saline also definitely doesn't hurt.
Great, but added 1 cl freshly squeezed lime juice the second time, which completed it
Great success. Vodka retains and preserves the delicate fragrance of fresh strawberries. Use the best strawberries that you can put your hands on, it's worth it.
This is lovely, I think it would have been good with a little bit of basil too, I might try adding it next time
The strawberries and mint nudge this delightfully from autumn back to late summer.

The fruit makes this special without making it much sweeter or much more complicated. The fruit balances the bitterness of the Negroni; use your preferred Negroni proportions. With muddled fruit I just shake rather than stir, and I strain as usual; fine straining is overly fussy for a drink that ain't a martini to begin with. This is a template that can be used with other fruits and with White Negronis as well, e.g., a White Peach Negroni. Experiment to match ingredient brands/styles to fruits.
Beautiful! I’ve played around with this too… substituting good quality berry sorbet for the strawberries, and Lillet Servir Tres Frais for the creme de frais liqueur…
Oh my. This is a surprisingly complex and delightful cocktail. For this English ex-pat it brought back fond memories of English beer. All that and a great cocktail too.
Works very good with calvados instead of vodka.
Nice, but could use some sugar syrup (1/2 fl oz).

What can I say - it took a little for me to appreciate how raw and aggressive W&N (and now Rum Fire) are, but after managing that, this is delicious. It's fruity, it has a little spice, it has a very heavy punch in the face of ester funk, it's great.
…And in the recipe…
Pleased to see the Stunning W&N in the shopping list now. My favourite 🤩
“Stun Wray” but no mention of the excellent Wray & Nephew Jamaican overproof rum?????
Overproof rum is the first ingredient.
quick question, any idea what this glass is called or where i could purchase it from?

We photographed this cocktail 15+ years ago, long before I started recording details of the glasses used. However, I suspect LSA (https://www.lsa-international.com/drinkware/champagne-glasses) but I doubt still available.
Quick question: why is the picture so distinctly red in the bottom, rather than purple or blue?
Good question and thanks for bringing to my attention. The answer is that this cocktail should be made with Crème Yvette and not Crème de Violette. I have now corrected the recipe.

As per David Wondrich I used Rye Whiskey and served in a coupe. Wowza! Rye slightly softened by the rum but boosted with extra rummy flavours. Dark red fruit and spice with a liquorice finish. In a word…intense.

A perfect evening cocktail. Sipping while watching a Baroque streaming concert. This is definitely a cocktail which benefits from a very, very long stir and some time to breathe. The bourbon is very forward with the other flavours enhancing the secondary taste. Softens as the ice melts. Perfect to unwind after the day.
As an alternative to an Old-Fashioned I found it improved with a little sweetness, I used a spoon of orange blossom honey.

I made this with Del Maguey Vida Clasico, Monin Cinnamon syrup, & Velvet Falernum. Earthy smokiness of the mezcal is front and center, with the blood orange juice balancing things out, and the rest adding some subtle complexity. Tasty if you like Mezcal.

Being found of blood orange juice, I wanted to taste cocktail recipes with it. We tried the Blood Orange Margarita yesterday and were disappointed. Tried this one today, heart full of hope. I did two versions : one with falernum and one with bénédictine as Deyan Kavrakov suggested (my girlfriend loves bénédictine). She liked both, I was disappointed by both. I find it too juicy and sweet (mostly due to a lack of acidity IMO) and too mezcal forward (I used Del Maguey Vida). I'll keep trying !

Excellent cocktail. Mezcal(or Reposado Tequila) and Cinnamon are established combination. I agree with G.M.G. about the distant lemongrass (Thai) echo. Being wonderful, as this cocktail is, I kindly suggest using 10ml Benedictine DOM instead of Falernum: outstanding.

A unique drink worth trying... My falernum was a haphazard mushing of 2 cloves, 4 lime peels, 6 thumbnail slices of ginger, and 15 ml amaretto, muddled to death before adding the other ingredients. My orange was Cara Cara, which is flavorful for sure but different enough from a blood orange to skew the flavors... I found this drink rather Vietnamese?!? - lemongrass, spicy green chile, sweet citrus... I'm very curious what y'all came up with.
I do not know how this rates five stars. The cinnamon overpowers all other flavour with a poor result. Not liked.
I didn’t have cinnamon simple syrup on hand, so I used regular simple syrup and then sprinkled cinnamon on top. This also worked! ?
Good but in desperate need of a dash of lime juice to take it to loftier heights.
Awesome name luv it OMG BRILLIANT
We have a whole collection of 1960s tiki mugs. This was perfect to serve in one of them. Interesting blend of flavours with the wonderful taste of the ginger beer. It went perfect with our lunch.
Just watched season three episode three of Venture Brothers, where this cocktail is referenced. Which is why I looked it up. Going to try it tomorrow. Go team Venture!

I went closer to the original recipe for this, and used only Rose's, but 1/2oz, and no pineapple or cherry, but rather a slice of orange and a sprig of mint. Not bad. Here's a video of me making it, straight after suffering through a presidential debate between Donald Trump and Joe Biden: https://youtu.be/695iXf6GS2Y
A great cocktail for a great cause…. The proportions are perfect in my opinion
So delicious. So crisp... clean... refreshing
Was a favorite when I made it with Myers's. Just made it with Bacardi 8yr and Torres 10yr brandy split with cognac. Still a favorite! All in on the Torres next time.
Very underwhelming. It tasted like a watered down Mai Tai. The Cognac was not at all prominent. It all just melded into one, in a not-so-good way.
Agree this is over sweet with store-bought orgeat. Drop the simple and reduce the syrup from 15ml to 10 or so and I think it's quite nice
I find it a bit oversweet, would try to reduce the sugar syrup or use the home-made Orgeat. The one from Giffard is good but tends to dominate the flavor & taste.
Tasty! might be my new fave
juicy and fresh. Goes down well. A nice after work drink. Sometimes we might drizzle a little homemade grenadine. I’ve been also doing a Campari drizzle and calling it a Dress Code.
Easily one of the best 'breeze' drinks I've tried. Served it up after shaking it with rather wet ice. Flavor intensity still potent.
I tried with Edelflower syrup 10 cc instead liquor and adding 10 cc vodka

Tried this twice. Didn't have wine... Used Cocchi Americano the first time. Pretty good... Used 50:50 Cocchi and prosecco. Almost as good... Definitely want to try this again but, alas, the bottle of SoCo I had for the last 3 years is finally gone and, oh well, might not get one any time soon... What a way for that bottle to go off into the sunset... Do try this! (21 May 2023, 2:28p)
Made this in an attempt to use up the unloved Southern Comfort we have and it was delicious!
A real favourite of mine. I wouldn't change a thing!

Very much enjoyed this. On first sips I thought a bit sweet and was going to make a "personal" note to try 1/2 oz elderflower next time. However, on drinking more, the perception of sweetness seemed to diminish. Overall a nicely balanced drink.
Hits the spot!
2.5Ml ? lol not in my watch. 5ML, no Cointreau, used Grand Marnie for a better drink. Complex, balanced, would never call this sweet, yet i like it. Saved to favorites.
As floral gin sours go, this is one of the best out there. With Pierre Ferrand Yuzu Curacao it's even better (if you like tart).
Far superior to the Corpse Reviver No. 2
Great cocktail! Also tried it with Limoncello in place of the Cointreau, it turned out to be an interesting twist on this drink.
I’ll second that!

Liked this one very much! Tart, floral, and with an added depth, thanks to the absinthe rinse. Also tried this one with about 7.5 ml of Galliano (also anise-forward) instead of absinthe, and was satisfied with the result.

Since my wife is no fan of bitter drinks, I omitted the kina and doubled the Lillet Blanc instead. The drink came our great, and deserving of its name: fresh and bright, but with a sturdy bourbon foundation. One of the better orange juice drinks I've found.
Jim Beam, Pierre Ferrand Curaçao, and Cocchi Americano. Very good, but the Curaçao takes over all the other ingredients.
While I'm not entirely sure if it qualifies as a Kina aromatized wine, I used Sacred English Amber Vermouth in its stead. Regardless, it was excellent! Definitely a repeat.

One of the more palatable oj drinks I've tried. Used Old Bardstown, Bauchant, Lillet Blanc, and Kina L'Aero d'Or. This will be a go-to when I'm trying to rid of that pesky unwanted oj. (8 Jun 2022, 1:10p)
Great balance of bitter and sweet, and since I had some blood oranges...Red Sky cocktail.
Made this one with Pierre Ferrand's Dry Curacao instead of Grand Marnier and it came out great. Great summer evening drink.
I made this with a homemade bergamot liqueur and a vintage bottle of Mandarine Napoléon given to me by my nan. Refreshing and delicious!
I really enjoyed this cocktail! Congratulations on your win!
This has made its way into our top ten list. Sometimes we use a mix of bourbon and rye, but it is better with good rye alone.
I still love this cocktail, but I’m always interested in riffs. Tonight I tried it with applejack, dry vermouth, and Belle de brillet pear liquor. Cardamom bitters, if you have it.
Very tasty. I like the spiciness of the rye quite a lot.
Great spirit forward cocktail. I would do this both as an evening sipper or aperitif with some sharp cheddar and salty crackers.
This was excellent but seemed a bit watery. Will try again, pre-chilling all ingredients before combining and then adding ice.
Used oude genever in place of vodka to add /some/ flavour. A very very tasty tonic drink.
Used Campari and only had Del Miguey Minero mezcal which has less smoke than Vida. Delicious drink, tonic and grapefruit really make this drink shine.
Superb’ I used Noilly Prat as the dry vermouth very enjoyable. One for the list
Delightfully light and pleasant!
Really simple, but really good! Great botanical, herbaceous vermouth suprisingly combining so well with pineapple and rum.
I didn't find this terribly sweet, but it has a nice velvety mouthfeel, with a lot of vermouth flavor. The rum recedes into the background. Generally a nice easy drink.

I used a fairly low quality gold rum, Dolin and homemade pomegranate syrup and didn’t find it particularly sweet. The vermouth dominated with the pineapple in the background.
